data.author: Roman Shtylman
data.message:
Add claude code review workflow (#853)

Adds an automated Claude code review workflow for pull requests. When a
non-draft PR is opened, synchronized, or marked ready for review, Claude
will automatically review the changes and post feedback as a comment.

**What's included:**

- **`.github/workflows/claude.yml`** - GitHub Actions workflow that:
- Triggers on PR events (opened, synchronize, ready_for_review,
reopened)
  - Skips draft PRs and dependabot PRs
- Uses concurrency control to cancel in-progress reviews when new
commits are pushed
- Configures Claude with read-only tools appropriate for the SDK
(`cargo`, `yarn`, `git`, `gh` commands)
- Posts review feedback as a sticky comment (updates in place rather
than creating new comments)

- **`.cursor/commands/review-pr.md`** - Review prompt that instructs
Claude to evaluate PRs for:
  - Correctness (logic errors, edge cases, race conditions)
  - Design & architecture (API clarity, separation of concerns)
  - Readability & maintainability
  - Performance & scalability
  - Security & safety
  - Testing & observability
  - Product & UX considerations

The workflow is modeled after the foxglove/app configuration but
simplified to remove app-specific features like auto-approval.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
derive: Implement ProtobufField for foxglove schemas (#854)

### Changelog
- rust: Added derive(Encode) support for structs with nested foxglove
schemas

### Docs
None

### Description
We currently don't support deriving `Encode` for structs that contain
nested foxglove schema types, which is a bit of a shame. This change
enables that support by implementing `ProtobufField` for foxglove
schemas.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
derive: Implement ProtobufField for other well-known types (#852)

### Changelog
- rust: Added derive(Encode) support for more well-known types

### Docs
None

### Description
When we implemented the derive macro for `Encode`, we didn't implement
it for the `Timestamp` and `Duration` well-known types, their chrono
equivalents, nor `Option<T> where T: Encode`. This change implements
`ProtobufField` for these types, so that the can be used as fields in a
struct that derives `Encode`.

data.author: Jacob Bandes-Storch
data.message:
playground: add set_layout method (#796)

### Changelog
The [playground](https://playground.foxglove.dev) now offers a
`playground.set_layout()` method.

### Docs

Included

### Description

This `playground` module does not exist in the SDK, it's just injected
at runtime.

Example:

```py
from foxglove.layouts import *
playground.set_layout(Layout(content=RawMessagesPanel()))
```

data.author: Joe Fox-Rabinovitz
data.message:
Added schemars-chrono feature (#851)

### Changelog

A new `schemars-chrono` Cargo feature enables the `chrono04` feature on
the underlying `schemars` dependency so that we can have automatic
schema generation for types including `chrono` timestamps.

### Docs

None

### Description

Building with `schemars` feature is nice, but sometimes you need
`chrono` support too. Enabling `chrono` feature does not enable
`chorno04` on the underlying `schemars` dependency, so you miss out on
some possibilities. The new feature ensures that you can generate
schemas with `chrono` date-time types.

---------

Co-authored-by: Jeff Zellner <jeffz@eml.cc>

build(deps): bump tar from 7.4.3 to 7.5.7 (#847) Bumps [tar](https://github.com/isaacs/node-tar) from 7.4.3 to 7.5.7.
Changelog

Sourced from tar's changelog.

Changelog

7.5

  • Added zstd compression support.
  • Consistent TOCTOU behavior in sync t.list
  • Only read from ustar block if not specified in Pax
  • Fix sync tar.list when file size reduces while reading
  • Sanitize absolute linkpaths properly
  • Prevent writing hardlink entries to the archive ahead of their file target

7.4

  • Deprecate onentry in favor of onReadEntry for clarity.

7.3

  • Add onWriteEntry option

7.2

  • DRY the command definitions into a single makeCommand method, and update the type signatures to more appropriately infer the return type from the options and arguments provided.

7.1

  • Update minipass to v7.1.0
  • Update the type definitions of write() and end() methods on Unpack and Parser classes to be compatible with the NodeJS.WritableStream type in the latest versions of @types/node.

7.0

  • Drop support for node <18
  • Rewrite in TypeScript, provide ESM and CommonJS hybrid interface
  • Add tree-shake friendly exports, like import('tar/create') and import('tar/read-entry') to get individual functions or classes.
  • Add chmod option that defaults to false, and deprecate noChmod. That is, reverse the default option regarding explicitly setting file system modes to match tar entry settings.
  • Add processUmask option to avoid having to call process.umask() when chmod: true (or noChmod: false) is set.

If your company or organization uses Python and would benefit from HTTP/2 support in Requests, pip, cloud SDKs, and thousands of other projects please consider contributing financially to ensure HTTP/2 support is developed sustainably and maintained for the long-haul.

Thank you for your support.

Security

  • Fixed a security issue where streaming API could improperly handle highly compressed HTTP content ("decompression bombs") leading to excessive resource consumption even when a small amount of data was requested. Reading small chunks of compressed data is safer and much more efficient now. (CVE-2025-66471 reported by @â€‹Cycloctane, 8.9 High, GHSA-2xpw-w6gg-jr37)

data.author: Jacob Bandes-Storch
data.message:
notebook: add opaque_layout param (#839)

### Changelog

`NotebookBuffer.show()` now has an `opaque_layout` parameter for loading
a layout from a JSON file exported from the Foxglove app.

### Docs

Updated docstring

### Description

Adds the ability to load a layout from a file like this:
```py
import foxglove
import json

nb_buffer = foxglove.init_notebook_buffer()

with open("file.json") as f:
    layout = json.load(f)

nb_buffer.show(opaque_layout=layout)
```

This previously existed as an undocumented feature but was removed in
#814.

Introduce v2 mod, plus Subscribe, Unsubscribe, and client MessageData binary messages (#812)

### Changelog
None

### Docs
None

### Description
Stand up `protocol::v2` mod, which is a copy of the boilerplate in
`protocol::v1` with some re-exports removed to squelch
dead-code/unused-import errors.

Introduce new v2 `Subscribe`, `Unsubscribe`, and server `MessageData`
messages. `Subscribe` and `Unsubscribe` have been migrated to binary
messages and replace their subscription ID field with a channel ID
field. Server `MessageData` was already binary, but replaces
subscription ID with channel ID.

Fixes: FLE-170

data.author: Sebastian Urbina
data.message:
Missing python build assets (#835) ### Changelog Fixes a bug where the `widget.js` static asset was missing from Python library builds, restoring Jupyter notebook integration. ### Docs None ### Description This PR addresses bug ERT-1463, where the `widget.js` static asset was missing from Python builds, specifically when wheels were built from the sdist artifact. This resulted in broken Jupyter notebook functionality for the `foxglove-sdk` Python library. The root cause was identified as: 1. An incorrect `tool.maturin.include` path in `pyproject.toml` that no longer matched the actual location of the generated `widget.js` file, causing it to be excluded from the sdist. 2. The `custom_build.py` script used `assert` statements, which could be skipped in CI environments running Python with optimizations, allowing builds to succeed even when the asset was not generated or found. This PR implements the following changes to resolve the issue and prevent future regressions: * **Corrected `maturin` include path**: The `pyproject.toml` has been updated to `python/foxglove/notebook/static/*` to correctly include `widget.js` in the sdist. * **Robust asset existence check**: The `assert` in `custom_build.py` has been replaced with `raise FileNotFoundError` to ensure that the build fails reliably if `widget.js` is not present, regardless of Python optimization settings. * **CI sdist validation**: A new step has been added to the `python.yml` workflow to explicitly verify that the generated sdist artifact contains the `widget.js` file, providing an early warning if the asset is missing from the package. These changes ensure that the Python library is correctly packaged with all necessary static assets, restoring full functionality for Jupyter notebook users, and adding a robust safeguard against similar issues in the future. CI will validate the sdist contents with the newly added check. Reviewers can manually verify by building the sdist locally and inspecting its contents.
BeforeAfter
Build does not include static assets: Build includes static assets:
Fixes: [ERT-1463](https://linear.app/foxglove/issue/ERT-1463) ---   --------- Co-authored-by: Cursor Agent

data.author: Chris Lalancette
data.message:
Increase the timeouts in the smoke tests. (#829)

### Changelog

None.

### Docs

None.

### Description

We've noticed some flakiness in the smoke_test tests, particularly when
running in the ROS infrastructure. When they fail, they are failing on
some of the timeouts waiting for things to connect.

We've also noticed that this is most likely to happen when the ROS
buildfarm is busy. That leads to the supposition that the 1 second
timeout we have on some of these checks is too short when the host is
busy.

The fix implemented here is to change the one second timeouts to 10
seconds everywhere. We don't expect we'll hit 10 seconds often (if
ever), but it should be enough buffer for the tests to pass even on
loaded systems.

In combination with this, we also remove the repeated tests. Running the
tests 50x on the ROS infrastructure seems excessive and also leads to
more chances to fail. As something of a compromise, we instead set our
GitHub workflows to run 50 times instead of the default being 50x.

Fixes:
[FLE-180](https://linear.app/foxglove/issue/FLE-180/investigate-flake-in-foxglove-bridge-smoketesttestsubscription)

@jtbandes FYI, particularly about reducing the number of times we run
these tests by default.

---------

Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette <clalancette@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette <chris.lalancette@foxglove.dev>

data.author: Chris Lalancette
data.message:
Force the ROS dockerfile to always do an apt-get dist-upgrade. (#830)

The comment in the code explains the situation, but I'll reproduce it
here in the commit as well:

The ROS docker images are only updated when the underlying Ubuntu layer
changes; this is a limitation of being an "official" docker image.
Additionally, ROS packages do not have minimum dependency requirements.
That is, ROS package "A" may have a dependency on "B", but it cannot
easily specify what version of "B" that it needs.
However, the latest versions of the ROS packages are always expected to
work together.

This means that we *always* have to do an
"apt-get dist-upgrade" before we install dependencies with "make deps"
below (which calls "rosdep install"). That ensures that we have the
latest versions of the ROS packages in the underlay and for what is
installed by rosdep.

Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette <chris.lalancette@foxglove.dev>

data.author: Andrew Madden
data.message:
Add Client Count Topic to Foxglove_bridge (#692) ### Changelog - Foxglove_bridge now publishes the number of foxglove clients connected to it under `/foxglove_bridge/client_count` ### Docs - I added a mention of the topic to the foxglove_bridge [readme](https://github.com/ndmmdn/foxglove-sdk/blob/feat-client-count/ros/src/foxglove_bridge/README.md) and that it requires a parameter to be set. ### Description - There are several examples where it is useful to no if a client is connected to the foxglove bridge, for example to pause other bandwidth intensive processes. Additionally, similar to the `who` command in bash, it can also be useful to know if there are multiple people connected to the same robot. Both of these cases can now be detected via the new client count topic. there exists the [test_callbacks](https://github.com/ndmmdn/foxglove-sdk/blob/feat-client-count/cpp/test_callbacks.cpp) test to allow testing on the c++ server level. Additionally, the new functionality was tested by build and running the foxglove_bridge as described in the readme. In a separate terminal, the `/foxglove_bridge/client_count` topic was subscribed to. Then using several foxglove instances on the same laptop, connections and disconnections were made to verify the client count is updated correctly.
BeforeAfter
This is a refactor/adaptation of [this foxglove_bridge PR](https://github.com/foxglove/ros-foxglove-bridge/pull/376) --------- Co-authored-by: Eric Lujan Co-authored-by: Eric Lujan

data.author: Chris Lalancette
data.message:
Fix a warning on newer versions of CMake. (#828)

### Changelog

None.

### Docs

None.

### Description

With CMake >= 3.24, we get a warning while building foxglove_bridge:

CMake Warning (dev) at
/usr/share/cmake-3.28/Modules/FetchContent.cmake:1331 (message):
The DOWNLOAD_EXTRACT_TIMESTAMP option was not given and policy CMP0135
is
  not set.  The policy's OLD behavior will be used.  When using a URL
download, the timestamps of extracted files should preferably be that of
  the time of extraction, otherwise code that depends on the extracted
  contents might not be rebuilt if the URL changes.  The OLD behavior
preserves the timestamps from the archive instead, but this is usually
not
  what you want.  Update your project to the NEW behavior or specify the
  DOWNLOAD_EXTRACT_TIMESTAMP option with a value of true to avoid this
  robustness issue.
Call Stack (most recent call first):
  CMakeLists.txt:79 (FetchContent_Declare)
This warning is for project developers.  Use -Wno-dev to suppress it.

Suppress this warning by doing what the text suggets and set our CMP0135
policy to NEW.

Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette <clalancette@gmail.com>

data.author: Blackjack
data.message:
C++: Add initial session_id support via WebSocketServerOptions (#822)

### Changelog

C++ SDK: Add optional `session_id` to WebSocketServerOptions for setting
an initial session ID when starting the server. Previously, `session_id`
could only be set after server start via `clearSession()`.

### Docs

None. This change adds an optional field that matches the existing
behavior in the Rust and Python SDKs, which already document this
parameter.

### Description

#### Problem

As reported in https://github.com/orgs/foxglove/discussions/1209, the
C++ SDK lacked the ability to set an initial `session_id` when starting
a server. This was inconsistent with the Rust and Python SDKs, which
both support setting `session_id` via server options.

#### Change

Added `session_id` field to WebSocketServerOptions in the C++ SDK,
allowing users to specify an initial session ID when creating a server:

```cpp
foxglove::WebSocketServerOptions options;
options.context = context;
options.name = "my-server";
options.session_id = "my-custom-session-id";  // Now supported!
auto server = foxglove::WebSocketServer::create(std::move(options));
```

This also required adding the `session_id` parameter to the C API
(foxglove_server_options struct) and its implementation, so the C++
layer can pass the value through to the underlying Rust SDK.

#### Testing

- Added new test case "Initial session id" in
`cpp/foxglove/tests/test_server.cpp` that verifies the session ID is
correctly set in the initial serverInfo message

Fixes: FLE-190

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Add serde for schema message types (#817)

### Changelog
- rust: Added serde implementations for schema messages

### Docs
None

### Description
This change adds `Serialize` and `Deserialize` implementations for
foxglove schemas in rust, under the `serde` feature.

For human-readable formats like JSON:
 - Enums are serialized as their string names (e.g., `"LINE_STRIP"`)
 - Binary data are serialized as base64-encoded strings

For binary formats:
 - Enums are serialized as i32 values
 - Binary data are serialized as raw bytes

I'm still not entierly sure I want to claim this is the basis for a
stable wire protocol, but I feel a bit better about it now that we have
the format-aware serde implementations for enums & binary data.

Resolves: https://github.com/orgs/foxglove/discussions/1207

Yarn's npm publish command does not support publishing from tarball
paths (e.g., `package.tgz`).

data.author: Eric Lujan
data.message:
Move message definitions, introduce version-specific binary message framing (#810)

### Changelog
None

### Docs
None

### Description
Preparation work for introducing v2 binary message definitions. This PR
includes the following changes intended to make it easier to introduce
new binary message definitions in the upcoming v2 protocol:

1. Create a v1-specific specialization for `{server,
client}::BinaryOpcode`. This enables us to migrate some messages like
`Subscribe` and `Unsubscribe` in v2 to binary messages without breaking
backwards compatibility.
2. Rename the `BinaryMessage` trait in `common` to `BinaryPayload`,
which contains logic for serializing the message's contents without
hardcoding version-specific opcodes or framing. This trait can be used
by binary messages shared across protocol versions. Each protocol
version implements its own `BinaryMessage` trait, which encompasses
logic for wrapping inner messages with version-appropriate framing.
3. Move tungstenite support to the v1 mod, to reflect its usage of
v1-specific `BinaryMessage` traits.
4. Move `v1::client::MessageData` to `common::client`, as it doesn't use
subscription IDs and the message definition will end up being identical
in v1 and v2.

Fixes: FLE-169

data.author: Roman Shtylman
data.message:
Add pull request template (#819)

This PR introduces a `pull_request_template.md` file in the `.github/`
directory to standardize pull request descriptions within the SDK
repository.

The problem this solves is the current lack of a consistent format for
PR descriptions, which can lead to incomplete information and make the
review process less efficient. By providing a template, we guide
contributors (including AI agents) to include essential details such as
a changelog summary, documentation links, a detailed description, and
before/after comparisons. This will improve clarity, consistency, and
streamline reviews.

The template used is based on the template found in `foxglove/app`
template at the time of this change.

data.author: Alexandre
data.message:
Add Point3InFrame schema (#813)

### Changelog
Add `Point3InFrame` schema for 3D points with `timestamp` and `frame_id`

### Docs
None

### Description
Adds `Point3InFrame`, a
[Point3](https://docs.foxglove.dev/docs/sdk/schemas/point-3) message
extended with `timestamp` and `frame_id`. This allows the app to publish
points with temporal and frame-of-reference metadata (something that
plain Point3 does not support). The schema is equivalent to ROS
[geometry_msgs/PointStamped](http://docs.ros.org/en/noetic/api/geometry_msgs/html/msg/PointStamped.html).

Although the schema is based on `Point3`, it can be used to also
represent 2D points by setting the `z` coordinate to `0`.

ERT-1119

data.author: Eric Lujan
data.message:
Move protocol types to `protocol` directory (#799)

### Changelog
None

### Docs
None

### Description
This PR exists to set up the structure for iterating on future versions
of the Foxglove protocol independently of the v1 protocol currently used
in the WebSocket implementation, without making breaking API changes
while in development. All changes should either be moving existing logic
or renaming messages specific to V1; no message definition changes or
new messages are introduced in this PR.

It contains the following changes:

1. Move Foxglove protocol message definitions from
`websocket::ws_protocol` to a new top-level `protocol` module.
Facilities and message definitions shared across protocol versions will
live in the `protocol::common` module.
2. Move `Subscribe`, `Unsubscribe`, and `MessageData` to their
respective `client` and `server` modules in a new `protocol::v1` module,
and rename them to add a `V1` suffix. The `ServerMessage` and
`ClientMessage` enums are similarly renamed to `ServerMessageV1` and
`ClientMessageV1` to reflect that they are refer to the set of message
definitions specific to protocol v1.
3. Update `websocket::ws_protocol` to provide re-exports and renaming of
types that now live in `protocol` for backwards-compatibility. **All
business logic in the `websocket` module still uses these re-exports for
now to keep the diff size sane; we will mechanically update them to
directly reference the `protocol` module later.**
4. Update top-level module and public exports in `lib.rs`.
5. Re-generate snapshots in their new subdirectories.

Fixes: FLE-164

<!-- CURSOR_SUMMARY -->
---

> [!NOTE]
> Establishes a new `protocol` module for Foxglove protocol types while
preserving backward compatibility.
> 
> - Introduces `protocol::{common, v1}` and migrates client/server
messages (JSON/Binary, schema, parameters, tungstenite) from
`websocket::ws_protocol` into these modules
> - Updates `websocket::ws_protocol` to re-export from `protocol::v1`
for non-breaking API usage; adjusts imports in code (e.g., `cloud_sink`
test) and enables `pub mod protocol` in `lib.rs`
> - Regenerates and relocates snapshots to new paths; no functional
changes to message formats or behavior
> 
> <sup>Written by [Cursor
Bugbot](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot) for commit
b1ae3decc6012c0492c0359af61413a813f71b4c. This will update automatically
on new commits. Configure
[here](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot).</sup>
<!-- /CURSOR_SUMMARY -->

---------

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
Refactor McapSink to use Sink trait for channel subscription control (#790)

### Changelog
None

### Docs
None

### Description
Previously, McapSink performed channel filtering in the `log()` method
after acquiring a mutex, which was inefficient as it processed every
message even for filtered channels.

This change refactors the implementation to use the Sink trait's
subscription control methods:
- `auto_subscribe()` returns false when a channel filter is present
- `add_channels()` filters channels at subscription time based on the
SinkChannelFilter

Benefits:
- Filtering happens before messages reach the sink
- No mutex contention for filtered channels
- Cleaner separation of concerns: channel_filter stored on McapSink, not
inside the mutex-protected WriterState
- Simplified channel_map (no longer needs Option<McapChannelId>)

All existing tests pass, including the updated channel filter test which
now properly exercises the subscription mechanism through a single
Context using McapWriter.

Fixes FLE-156

data.author: Mak NazeÄiÄ‡-Andrlon
data.message:
[python] Add support for `disable_seeking` MCAP writer option (#800)

### Changelog
* python: add support for the `disable_seeking` MCAP writer option,
allowing writing to non-seekable streams (e.g. network sockets).
* python: add `McapWritable` protocol describing minimal IO needed for
writing MCAP.

### Docs
None

### Description

#798 added support for opening an MCAP writer on file-like objects.
However, an important use case is writing to network streams (e.g. HTTP
or WebSocket connections). This PR allows for this in Python by exposing
the `disable_seeking` option from Rust. Similarly to Rust, the file-like
object must still have a `seek` method, except it only needs to support
`seek(0, SEEK_CUR)` and `seek(current_position, SEEK_SET)`.

This PR also loosens the signature of `open_mcap` by allowing it to take
an `McapWritable`, a newly added Python protocol which only requires
`write`, `seek` and `flush`. This is strictly more general than
`BinaryIO`, but `BinaryIO` is retained in the signature for
documentation clarity.

Fixes: FIRE-247

data.message:
[python] Support opening MCAP writers on file-like objects (#798)

### Changelog
* Python: extend `open_mcap()` to also accept file-like objects. 

### Docs
None

### Description

This PR extends `open_mcap()` to accept file-like objects in addition to
file paths, enabling MCAP recording to any Python object implementing
`write()`, `seek()`, and `flush()`. This allows using in-memory buffers,
network streams, or similar as MCAP writing sinks.

Closes: FIRE-248

<!-- CURSOR_SUMMARY -->
---

> [!NOTE]
> Adds file-like object support for MCAP writing in Python.
> 
> - Extends `open_mcap(path, ...)` to accept `str | Path | BinaryIO`;
updates stubs and docstrings in
`python/foxglove/_foxglove_py/__init__.pyi`
> - Implements `PyFileLikeWriter` and `WriterInner` in Rust
(`src/mcap.rs`) to adapt Python objects with `write/seek/flush` to
`Write + Seek`; updates `PyMcapWriter` to use `BufWriter<WriterInner>`
> - Updates `open_mcap` in `src/lib.rs` to handle either filesystem
paths (with `allow_overwrite`) or file-like objects (ignoring overwrite)
> - Adds tests in `python/foxglove/tests/test_mcap.py` for writing to
`BytesIO`, validating MCAP magic bytes, and reading back via
`mcap.reader`

data.author: Sander Pick
data.message:
MCAP attachments (#791)

### Changelog

Add `McapWriterHandle::attach()` method and `McapAttachment` type to
enable writing attachments to MCAP files via the Rust SDK.

### Docs

Is there a docs repo?

### Description

This PR exposes the mcap crate's attachment functionality through the
foxglove SDK, allowing users to store arbitrary binary data
(configuration files, calibration data, images, etc.) alongside messages
in MCAP recordings.

#### Changes
- Added `McapAttachment` type re-export from the mcap crate
- Added `McapSink::attach()` internal implementation
- Added `McapWriterHandle::attach()` public API with documentation and
example
- Added comprehensive tests for attachment functionality

#### Usage example
```rust
use std::borrow::Cow;
use foxglove::{McapWriter, McapAttachment};

let mcap = McapWriter::new()
    .create_new_buffered_file("test.mcap")
    .expect("create failed");

mcap.attach(&McapAttachment {
    log_time: 0,
    create_time: 0,
    name: "config.json".to_string(),
    media_type: "application/json".to_string(),
    data: Cow::Borrowed(br#"{"setting": true}"#),
}).expect("attach failed");

mcap.close().expect("close failed");
```

#### Testing
Added unit tests for basic attachment, multiple attachments, and error
handling when attaching after close. All 212 tests pass with `--features
unstable`. Manual testing works:
```
$ mcap info test.mcap 
library:   foxglove-sdk-rust/v0.0.0                                    
profile:                                                               
messages:  3204                                                        
duration:  1m22.913993797s                                             
start:     2025-12-10T13:34:08.054447689-07:00 (1765398848.054447689)  
end:       2025-12-10T13:35:30.968441486-07:00 (1765398930.968441486)  
compression:
	lz4: [732/732 chunks] [1.36 GiB/968.95 MiB (30.44%)] [11.69 MiB/sec] 
chunks:
	max uncompressed size: 1.91 MiB
	max compressed size: 1.34 MiB
	overlaps: no
channels:
	[redacted]
channels: 5
attachments: 1
metadata: 1
```

<!-- CURSOR_SUMMARY -->
---

> [!NOTE]
> Adds support for writing MCAP attachments via
`McapWriterHandle::attach` and re-exports `McapAttachment`, with sink
implementation and tests.
> 
> - **Public API**
> - Re-export `McapAttachment` from `mcap` in `rust/foxglove/src/lib.rs`
and `rust/foxglove/src/mcap_writer.rs`.
> - Add `McapWriterHandle::attach(&McapAttachment)` with docs and
example.
> - **MCAP Sink**
> - Implement `McapSink::attach(&mcap::Attachment)` to write
attachments.
> - **Tests**
> - Add unit tests for attachments: basic write, multiple attachments,
and error after close in `rust/foxglove/src/mcap_writer/mcap_sink.rs`
tests.
>

Bugbot](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot) for commit

data.author: Eric Lujan
data.message:
Add did_seek field to PlaybackState (#777)

### Changelog
None

### Docs
None

### Description
Add a `did_seek` field to the `PlaybackState` message, which indicates
that the server time has jumped enough to constitute a discontinuity in
playback. This is used to clear panels in the Foxglove player.


<!-- CURSOR_SUMMARY -->
---

> [!NOTE]
> Adds a `did_seek` boolean to `PlaybackState` and wires it through C,
C++, and Rust APIs, updating the binary layout, server bridging, and
tests.
> 
> - **Protocol / Binary wire format**:
> - Extend `PlaybackState` with `bool did_seek` and insert a 1-byte flag
in the binary message (after `current_time`, before `request_id`),
adjusting header size and field order (`current_time` before
`playback_speed`).
> - Update parsing/serialization in Rust (`to_bytes`, `parse_binary`)
and C++ test helpers; refresh insta snapshots.
> - **C API**:
> - Add `did_seek` to `struct foxglove_playback_state` in
`c/include/...`.
> - Propagate via FFI: `FoxglovePlaybackState` includes `did_seek`;
`to_native()` maps it; server initializes and forwards it in
callbacks/broadcasts.
> - **C++ SDK**:
>   - Add `did_seek` to `foxglove::PlaybackState`.
> - Bridge `did_seek` in callback glue and
`WebSocketServer::broadcastPlaybackState`.
> - **Rust server/tests**:
> - Add `did_seek` to `PlaybackState` type and all usages; set/verify in
tests (including playback control and broadcast).
> 
> <sup>Written by [Cursor
Bugbot](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot) for commit
f0cc282fd011bc5130d91c6048649a303079de1e. This will update automatically
on new commits. Configure
[here](https://cursor.com/dashboard?tab=bugbot).</sup>
<!-- /CURSOR_SUMMARY -->

data.message:
C/C++: allow custom write implementations for MCAP writer (#764) ### Changelog - C++: added CustomWriter to allow C++ clients to write MCAP to targets other than the filesystem. ### Docs Detailed in docstrings. Will add an example before merge. ### Description Today Rust clients can create MCAP writers that wrap an arbitrary std::io::Write implementation of their own. This does not work in C++ or in python. This PR adds that ability to the C++ SDK. This is useful for anyone who want to log MCAP but not to a traditional filesystem - they may want to log to a socket, or they may want to intercept writes before they go to the filesystem. ## TODO - [x] Unit tests - [x] Example code

data.author: Caidy
data.message:
foxglove_bridge: fix message format error when using cache (#769)

### Changelog
<!-- Write a one-sentence summary of the user-impacting change (API,
UI/UX, performance, etc) that could appear in a changelog. Write "None"
if there is no user-facing change -->

Fix message format error when using cache, foxglove shows "Failed to
parse channel schema".

### Docs

<!-- Link to a Docs PR, tracking ticket in Linear, OR write "None" if no
documentation changes are needed. -->

None

### Description

<!-- Describe the problem, what has changed, and motivation behind those
changes. Pretend you are advocating for this change and the reader is
skeptical. -->

foxglove_bridge contains a hard-coded issue when retrieving cached
message files, causing IDL files to be correctly recognized only on the
first attempt. Subsequent cached requests return an incorrect format.

Here is the first discussions:
https://github.com/orgs/foxglove/discussions/1195

This fix was tested on my computer, both MSG and IDL worked well.

data.author: Eric Lujan
data.message:
Create WebSocket server handler for PlaybackControlRequest (#735)

### Changelog
None

### Docs
None

### Description
Add in Rust SDK functionality for the messages introduced in #728;
namely:
- Introduce the `RangedPlayback` capability, which indicates that a
server connected over WebSocket is providing data from a fixed playback
time range.
- Introduce the `playback_time_range` option in `ServerOptions`, where
the server is expected to declare the time range of the data it is
playing back. This option will implies the `RangedPlayback` capability
and will enable it if it is not already enabled
- Add the `on_playback_control_request` function to the `ServerListener`
trait, which allows a server to receive playback control requests from
the client. It requires the server to send a `PlaybackState` message in
response.
- Add the `broadcast_playback_state` function, which allows a server to
broadcast a change in its playback state in response to anything other
than a `PlaybackControlRequest` message (for example, reaching the end
of playback or an external process pausing playback).

These changes are currently guarded behind the `unstable` FF and
excluded from documentation.

data.message:
Revert "Ignore foxglove_bridge in ROS1 (#703)" (#757)

This reverts commit 3a121300c21fef80b593b65b7fdcdbffee52fd10.

### Changelog
None

### Docs
None

### Description
Revert #703, as it was found to cause issues with ROS Index ignoring the
`foxglove_bridge` package and likely will prevent blooming the next
release. This is because various ROS 2 tools, including rosindex and
bloom, [are aware of
CATKIN_IGNORE](https://github.com/ros-infrastructure/rosindex/blob/79e54aba8267da21bdb995648366316782e46fb0/_plugins/rosindex_generator.rb#L471)
even for ROS 2 distributions.

Fixes #756

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
python: Fix windows wheel builds (#738)

In #690, we worked around a CI issue, but we went about it the wrong
way. By turning off `maturin-action`'s `--find-interpreter`, we ended up
building only a single wheel against python 3.9 for windows x64.

The root of the original problem that #690 was trying to tackle, is that
github's `windows-latest` runner doesn't have _any_ 32-bit pythons
installed. This change uses `setup-python` to install the versions we
care about, and restores the use of `maturin-action`'s
`--find-interpreter` so that we build against them.

```
Archive:  wheels-windows-x86_64.zip
    testing: foxglove_sdk-0.15.2-cp310-cp310-win_amd64.whl   OK
    testing: foxglove_sdk-0.15.2-cp312-cp312-win_amd64.whl   OK
    testing: foxglove_sdk-0.15.2-cp311-cp311-win_amd64.whl   OK
    testing: foxglove_sdk-0.15.2-cp313-cp313-win_amd64.whl   OK
    testing: foxglove_sdk-0.15.2-cp314-cp314-win_amd64.whl   OK
    testing: foxglove_sdk-0.15.2-cp39-cp39-win_amd64.whl   OK

Archive:  wheels-windows-x86.zip
    testing: foxglove_sdk-0.15.2-cp310-cp310-win32.whl   OK
    testing: foxglove_sdk-0.15.2-cp311-cp311-win32.whl   OK
    testing: foxglove_sdk-0.15.2-cp312-cp312-win32.whl   OK
    testing: foxglove_sdk-0.15.2-cp313-cp313-win32.whl   OK
    testing: foxglove_sdk-0.15.2-cp314-cp314-win32.whl   OK
    testing: foxglove_sdk-0.15.2-cp39-cp39-win32.whl   OK
```

Fixes: FG-13419
Fixes: #729

data.author: Sebastian Urbina
data.message:
notebook: set up jupyter notebook widget (#663)

### Changelog
<!-- Write a one-sentence summary of the user-impacting change (API,
UI/UX, performance, etc) that could appear in a changelog. Write "None"
if there is no user-facing change -->
Add Python notebook integrations

### Docs

<!-- Link to a Docs PR, tracking ticket in Linear, OR write "None" if no
documentation changes are needed. -->
https://github.com/foxglove/docs/pull/1022

### Description

This PR adds the notebook integration for Python, particularly:
- Adds the notebook integration using Anywidget
- Uses @foxglove/embed to show Foxglove in a notebook
- Provides an API to load a layout from a file
- Provides an API to visualize messages from buffer associated with a
Context
- Add build script and update CI jobs where necessary
- Adds API docs

The integration is shipped as an extra dependency of the foxglove-sdk
package. To install, run the following command:

```bash
pip install foxglove-sdk[notebook]
```


https://drive.google.com/file/d/1BSLsBt6WSsnnj3a6G-hWsivNr8vzNZnp/view?usp=sharing

### How to test?

1. Clone this repo
1. Follow instructions
[here](https://github.com/foxglove/foxglove-sdk/blob/sebastian/ert-577-set-up-widget-package/python/foxglove-sdk/CONTRIBUTING.md)
to setup the repo for local development
1. Activate the virtual environment created by poetry
    ```bash
    eval $(poetry env activate)
    ```
1. Install Jupyter
    ```bash
    pip install jupyterlab
    ```
1. Build and install the sdk locally, including the notebook extra
dependencies
    ```bash
    pip install -e ".[notebook]"
    ```
1. Launch Jupyter
    ```bash
    jupyter lab
    ```

https://drive.google.com/file/d/12Ftbu-qpXIdwSJln4_Dy7FefcoJjctO1/view?usp=drive_link

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Include ROS distro information in server info message (#716)

In order to support click-to-publish in the 3d panel on a WebSocket
connection, the ServerInfo message needs to include the value of the
ROS_DISTRO environment variable. (Publishing is only supported for ROS
sources right now.) Prior versions of the Bridge included this but the
new releases for ROS2 do not, and the SDK doesn't expose a mechanism for
it.

This PR adds an undocumented `server_info` option to the Rust and C++
server options. This metadata will be included in the ServerInfo message
sent to the app. The only use case today is to convey ROS distro, but we
may extend in the future. I named this "server_info" instead of
"metadata" since it's specifically for information sent to clients, but
am open to better names.

This does not add python support, and we have no workarounds for people
wanting to spoof support for 3d publishing there. ERT-689 covers this
(bringing 3d publish support to non-ROS systems).

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Python example: logging config and filtering (#713)

This adds a Python example demonstrating logging configuration and
filtering which might be closer to a real-world application.

For convenience in scripts, `foxglove.set_log_level()` will configure
basic logging if it hasn't already been; for brevity, this is what our
other examples use. The reference docs note this, and recommend
configuring logging yourself, but we don't show you how.

This also adds rudimentary support for configuration of logging via
`FOXGLOVE_LOG_LEVEL` (env var). It supports a subset of the env_logger
format, excluding regex filters. (Note there's an `env_filter` crate,
but it doesn't expose an API to let us work with the pyo3 logger here.)
This moves python towards consistency with other languages, but one
issue is that module names don't match the user-facing python libraries.
We could document the level-only arguments ("debug", "info", etc) and
omit mention of more targeted config â€”Â this is what we do with C++. But
I've omitted it from the example for this reason.

data.author: james-rms
data.message:
remove language referring to optional fields (#699) ### Changelog None. ### Docs Is docs ### Description Foxglove schemas do not have a notion of optional fields, but some docstrings refer to varying behavior based on "provided" values. This PR updates the language to describe behavior of empty vs. non-empty values in these cases. I've checked that the app behaves as described for `LinePrimitive` and `TriangleListPrimtive` colors.
BeforeAfter

data.author: james-rms
data.message:
JSONSchema: mark all properties required (#682) ### Changelog - *Breaking*: Foxglove JSON schemas now require all object properties to be defined. This updates the JSONSchema representation of Foxglove schemas to match the requirements of the app, as well as the requirements of ROS and Flatbuffer schemas. - Note: The Foxglove app does not enforce this requirement at runtime, so existing messages will not be validated differently within Foxglove. ### Docs Self-documenting. ### Description Today whether or not a field is required in a foxglove schema message depends on the schema encoding you use. Today what the app can assume is in a message depends on the encoding: :white_check_mark:ROS(1|2)(msg|idl): all fields are required â“ : Protobuf: no fields are required by the serializer. the deserializer will fill in zero values for fields with primitive types. fields with nested struct types are set to null by the deserializer. :x:jsonschema: no fields are required. :white_check_mark:Flatbuffer: all fields are required. This PR updates our JSONSchemas to require fields, which brings us closer to agreement between all encodings. It's impossible to require fields in a protobuf schema (that's left to the application to enforce).
BeforeAfter

data.message:
Python: support filtering logging sinks by topic (#504)

This builds on #500 to bring channel filters to Python.

This constructs a new channel descriptor when the filter is called, but
this isn't called frequently since we cache the results of this for the
MCAP sink.

The example is generally the same as the Rust one; I removed the point

wasn't demonstrating much on its own there.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Support channel filtering in c/c++ (#519)

This wires up C++ and C to the sink channel filtering on MCAPs and WS
Server. I followed existing patterns set by callbacks and fetch-asset,
for the most part. The filter function is called once per channel per
sink, and the result is cached.

The example is generally the same as Rust and python, with point clouds
logged to one MCAP and some lightweight state to another (and both to
the app).

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Rust: support filtering logging sinks by topic (#500)

This implements sink filtering, so that a user can (for example) log
"heavy" topics to a different MCAP than the rest of their data, but
still log all messages to a WS server in the same context. Python and
C++ will follow, but released at the same time.

The example and tests (which make up most of the changeset here)
illustrate the usage. I started with a version that also allowed you to
change filtering on the sink after the fact, but decided to keep it
simpler for now.

data.message:
Add note to CameraCalibration that we do not support Tx and Ty values (#665)

Our `CameraCalibration` documentation makes it appear like we support
the `Tx` and `Ty` parameters of the projection matrix when in fact we
don't. This PR updates the documentation in the message to indicate we
do not currently support those parameters. We do leave the parameters
present so users can continue providing conventional projection matrix
values.

data.author: dependabot[bot]
data.message:
build(deps): bump tracing-subscriber from 0.3.19 to 0.3.20 (#633) Bumps [tracing-subscriber](https://github.com/tokio-rs/tracing) from 0.3.19 to 0.3.20.
Release notes

Sourced from tracing-subscriber's releases.

tracing-subscriber 0.3.20

Security Fix: ANSI Escape Sequence Injection (CVE-TBD)

Impact

Previous versions of tracing-subscriber were vulnerable to ANSI escape sequence injection attacks. Untrusted user input containing ANSI escape sequences could be injected into terminal output when logged, potentially allowing attackers to:

  • Manipulate terminal title bars
  • Clear screens or modify terminal display
  • Potentially mislead users through terminal manipulation

In isolation, impact is minimal, however security issues have been found in terminal emulators that enabled an attacker to use ANSI escape sequences via logs to exploit vulnerabilities in the terminal emulator.

Solution

Version 0.3.20 fixes this vulnerability by escaping ANSI control characters in when writing events to destinations that may be printed to the terminal.

Affected Versions

All versions of tracing-subscriber prior to 0.3.20 are affected by this vulnerability.

Recommendations

Immediate Action Required: We recommend upgrading to tracing-subscriber 0.3.20 immediately, especially if your application:

  • Logs user-provided input (form data, HTTP headers, query parameters, etc.)
  • Runs in environments where terminal output is displayed to users

Migration

This is a patch release with no breaking API changes. Simply update your Cargo.toml:

[dependencies]
tracing-subscriber = "0.3.20"

Acknowledgments

We would like to thank zefr0x who responsibly reported the issue at security@tokio.rs.

If you believe you have found a security vulnerability in any tokio-rs project, please email us at security@tokio.rs.

Commits
  • 4c52ca5 fmt: fix ANSI escape sequence injection vulnerability (#3368)
  • f71cebe subscriber: impl Clone for EnvFilter (#3360)
  • 3a1f571 Fix CI (#3361)
  • e63ef57 chore: prepare tracing-attributes 0.1.30 (#3316)
  • 6e59a13 attributes: fix tracing::instrument regression around shadowing (#3311)
  • e4df761 tracing: update core to 0.1.34 and attributes to 0.1.29 (#3305)
  • 643f392 chore: prepare tracing-attributes 0.1.29 (#3304)
  • d08e7a6 chore: prepare tracing-core 0.1.34 (#3302)
  • 6e70c57 tracing-subscriber: count numbers of enters in Timings (#2944)
  • c01d4fd fix docs and enable CI on main branch (#3295)
  • Additional commits viewable in compare view

data.author: Chris Lalancette
data.message:
Update the workaround to find the service typesupport handle. (#673)

### Changelog

None.

### Docs

None.

### Description

The GenericClient implementation in foxglove_bridge needs to get a
service typesupport handle in order to initialize itself.

In late 2023, the rclcpp::get_service_typesupport_handle() API was added
to ROS as a one-call way to get the typesupport handle for services.
That means that all ROS 2 releases since Iron have that API.

Humble does not have that particular API. However, since late 2024, it
does include the underlying rosidl API, so we can call that without
resorting to hacks to find the symbol in the library. In Humble prior to
that 2024 release, we need that symbol lookup hack.

That leads to this patch. If we are on a new enough rclcpp, we use
rclcpp::get_service_typesupport_handle(). If we are on a newer version
of Humble, we use the underlying rosidl API.

<!-- In addition to unit tests, describe any manual testing you did to
validate this change. -->

All tests succeed (run with `colcon test`) on Kilted, Jazzy, Humble, and
older Humble (prior to the symbol being available).

Fixes FG-13130

---------

Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette <chris.lalancette@foxglove.dev>

data.author: Matthew Harrison
data.message:
Fix memory leak in generic_client allocate_message (#667)

### Changelog

None

### Docs

None

### Description

We have found that with a high volume of service calls the memory usage
of the foxglove bridge grows unbounded. Using valgrind with memcheck,
the source of some of these definitely lost blocks was found to be the
`allocate_message` function in `generic_client`, where a buffer has
memory allocated using the `MessageMembers` `_init_function` which is
freed using `free`. This seems to mean that if a message type contains
pointers, the memory pointed to will never be freed.

To remedy this, we instead call `members->_fini_function` , which the
Message-specific clean-up functions (as documented
[here](https://docs.ros.org/en/ros2_packages/humble/api/rosidl_typesupport_introspection_cpp/generated/structrosidl__typesupport__introspection__cpp_1_1MessageMembers__s.html)
and implemented
[here](https://github.com/ros2/rosidl/blob/4edcac1c0aa162d4c231389811c105214c74a439/rosidl_typesupport_introspection_cpp/resource/msg__type_support.cpp.em#L253)

Skip cloudflare deploy step if the PR is from an external fork. (#672)

### Changelog

None.

None.

### Description

That's because the cloudflare deploy step requires secrets, which are
not passed to a job running on a PR from an external fork. By skipping
it, we lose a bit of convenience, but given that the number of PRs from
external forks is minimal, this should be OK.

You can see what happens with an external fork by looking at the CI in
https://github.com/foxglove/foxglove-sdk/pull/670 (ignore the CI/rust
failure, that's a different problem handled by #671).

data.author: Eric Lujan
data.message:
Bump ROS package version to 3.2.0 (#664)

### Changelog
- Release v3.2.0 of `foxglove_msgs` and `foxglove_bridge` ROS packages

### Docs
CHANGELOG.rst for packages are updated, will also update release notes
when cutting a GitHub release against main and creating tag
`ros-v3.2.0`.

### Description
Bump ROS package versions to 3.2.0, which includes enhancements to
`foxglove_msgs` and is the first version of `foxglove_bridge` based on
the SDK targeted for general release.

After this PR merges, I will:
1. Run `bloom` and roll out to all current ROS versions (`rolling`,
`jazzy`, `kilted`, and `humble`), by updating the upstream repo and tags
in
[ros2-gbp/foxglove_bridge-release](https://github.com/ros2-gbp/foxglove_bridge-release/blob/master/tracks.yaml).
This will also release `foxglove_msgs` under this repo going forward. We
should update the name of this repo to `foxglove_sdk-release` if
possible to reflect the expanded scope).
2. Deprecate
[ros2-gbp/ros_foxglove_msgs](https://github.com/ros2-gbp/ros_foxglove_msgs-release),
since it'll be a redundant/duplicate pointer to the Foxglove SDK repo.

Before I move forward with these changes, @clalancette: it would be
helpful to get your take on any ordering gotchas that could happen with
bloom or the ROS build farm. I didn't see any documentation about doing
a repo handover like this (understandable, given that it comes up
infrequently), so your advice on any hidden dangers will be greatly
appreciated to avoid inadvertently breaking our packages during the
changeover.

Fixes: FLE-33

data.author: Eric Lujan
data.message:
Update Foxglove Bridge to SDK v0.14.2, change version to match foxglove_msgs (#662)

### Changelog
- Fixes linker errors when building Foxglove Bridge from source against
ROS Humble

### Docs
None

### Description
Update Foxglove Bridge to point to an SDK version that builds properly
on Ubuntu 22.04, which is the target OS for ROS humble. This is expected
to resolve the current failing jobs to build the Foxglove Bridge Docker
image for Humble.

I'm also using this opportunity to update the ROS package's version
number from `0.14.1` to `3.1.0` to match `foxglove_msgs`. This is to
satisfy the constraint that ROS `bloom` will only allow publishing
packages if all packages in the same repo have the exact same version
number (see [the bloom documentation]()):
> Even if you do not use catkin_prepare_release, you must have one or
more valid package.xml(s) with the same version and a matching tag in
your upstream repository.

This is unfortunate, as this particular version bump does not warrant
jumping ahead 3 major versions. I suppose you could try to make the
argument that "this is the first SDK-based Foxglove Bridge that we
intend to release to rosdistro", and this does constitute a major
version change from the perspective of people who apt install Foxglove
Bridge, but the real reason is to work to the requirements that ROS
imposes.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
python: Update type stubs for jedi compatibility (#657)

### Changelog
None

### Docs
None

### Description
This change seeks to resolve the sadness preventing jedi from loading
type information from the foxglove SDK.

The two major blockers that needed to be resolved:
- Jedi does not understand `Class.__new__`; it only looks for
`Class.__init__`.
- Jedi does not understand non-static defaults (`"".to_string()`,
`vec![]`, etc.). Turns out sphinx doesn't either. These get converted to
`Ellipsis` in the docs (cf.,
[SceneEntity](https://foxglove.github.io/foxglove-sdk/python/api/schemas.html#foxglove.schemas.SceneEntity)).

While I was there, I also decided to standardize on `X | Y` for
`Union[X, Y]` and using standard keywords for list/dict/tuple types. The
old syntax was intended for backwards compatibility for python 3.9, but
it looks verbose and outdated. We can work around the compatibility
issue by adding a `from __future__ import annotations` in .py files; for
.pyi files, it doesn't really matter. I don't expect this to have any
practical impact since type-checkers and LSPs have their own logic for
parsing type hints. I've updated python to 3.13 for the docs CI
workflow, to deal with these changes.

data.author: james-rms
data.message:
C++ data loaders: include foxglove SDK for message serialization (#626) ### Changelog ### Docs ### Description Based on https://github.com/foxglove/foxglove-sdk/pull/624 This PR changes the foxglove C++ Data loader SDK to include a limited subset of the Foxglove SDK. This allows data loader developers to serialize Foxglove message using the schemas available in the SDK. Also: - includes the data loader SDK as a `.zip` bundle in foxglove SDK releases. - Changes the C++ SDK generation code to include #ifdefs around unsupported functionality for WASM builds - Changes the Arena on-stack size to 8KB. This still allows small messages to be serialized without heap allocation, but avoids blowing up the stack on WASM (where the total stack size is 1MB) - Updates the C++ data loader example included to demonstrate message serialization using the foxglove SDK.
BeforeAfter

data.author: james-rms
data.message:
foxglove-c: enable building for WASM32 targets (#624) ### Changelog - C: enable a minimal build for wasm32 targets, that includes Foxglove schema struct definitions and serialization functionality only. ### Docs ### Description We want to be able to use the foxglove SDK from within WASM data loaders to serialize foxglove messages. To do this we need to build the core foxglove serialization functionality as WASM. This PR moves all of the code that does I/O in foxglove-c out of `lib.rs` and into modules, which are conditionally included in the library based on architecture. It uses cbindgen's `[defines]` feature to put `#ifdef __wasm32__` around all of these features in the generated header file. NOTE: `__wasm32__` is not defined in any standard, but it is what the WASI SDK Clang implementation uses, and that's the toolchain that we specify for the data loader SDK.
BeforeAfter

data.author: Eric Lujan
data.message:
Add WSS support to Foxglove Bridge (#622)

### Changelog
- [Foxglove Bridge] Foxglove Bridge now supports WebSocket Secure (WSS)
as a transport.

### Docs
`README.md` updated to reflect new WSS ROS params.

### Description
Integrate changes from #560 to configure TLS/WSS in Foxglove Bridge.
Users can now supply ROS params to enable WSS and specify where their
certificate and private keys are located.

Manually tested with a local self-signed certificate/key and was able to
connect web and desktop apps to a local WSS server.

Fixes: FLE-9

data.author: james-rms
data.message:
C/C++ add schema() getter function for all builtin schemas (#616) ### Changelog - C: add `foxglove__schema()` for Foxglove schemas excluding Timestamp and Duration. - C++: add `::schema()` for Foxglove schemas excluding Timestamp and Duration. These allow the caller to retrieve runtime schema information that can be used with MCAP or the Data Loader API. ### Docs None ### Description Following up from #614 , adds a getter for the schema information to the C/C++ SDK. These mirror the similar `get_schema()` methods already available in Python and Rust. This again allows data loaders to provide schema information to the foxglove app in pull control flow rather than push.
BeforeAfter

data.author: james-rms
data.message:
add encode method on all schemas (#614) ### Changelog #### Added - C: added `foxglove_..._encode` implementations for all foxglove schemas (excluding Timestamp and Duration). - C++: added `::encode()` methods to all foxglove schemas (excluding Timestamp and Duration). - Python: added `self.encode()` methods to all foxglove schemas (excluding Timestamp and Duration). These can be used to directly serialize the message as protobuf. ### Docs None. ### Description When attempting to use the foxglove SDK within a data loader, the user needs to encode messages and return them to the caller, rather than pass them to a Channel. The data loader framework code can't be wrapped in such a way to make the Channel abstraction make sense, because messages are "pulled" from data loaders rather than "pushed" into a channel. Therefore, this PR adds encoding capability to C and C++ bindings (and Python for completeness). The C/C++ wrappers write into a preallocated buffer, and return an error if the buffer is not large enough. This allows the caller to use whatever allocation scheme suits them. ### Discussion I'm not so sure about the language to use here in the documentation. Should I explicitly say that these are encoded as protobuf? They use whatever `Encode` implementation the underlying struct uses, which we define for ourselves for our built-in schemas. Do we ever want to implement other encodings for our own schemas and channels, or are we happy to define that as Protobuf for now?
BeforeAfter

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Support wss connections for bridge (#560)

This adds initial support for secure websocket connections (wss) in a
form that supports the ros-foxglove-bridge interface. Support is behind
an undocumented "tls" feature. We plan to expose this in the bridge
prior to SDK users in general. This does not contain any support for
Python.

The server accepts the contents of a PEM-formatted x509 certificate and
a PEM-formatted pkcs8 key. I tested this with a 4096-bit RSA key and
self-signed certificate, by trusting the cert in my keychain, using the
examples (which take file path arguments).

Under the hood, this uses rustls. Currently, it also uses
rustls-native-certs; TBD what we need to support here.

data.author: Adrian Macneil
data.message:
Dependabot: Ignore minor and patch updates (#610)

Our cargo packages are used as libraries, which means we are permissive
on which versions of dependencies are used. Cargo uses [caret ranges by
default](https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/specifying-dependencies.html#caret-requirements).

We therefore get very little value from endless PRs like
https://github.com/foxglove/foxglove-sdk/pull/606 which make minor
updates to our lockfile. We can manually update the lockfile
occasionally without spamming our git history.

Using learnings from https://github.com/foxglove/ros-typescript/pull/83.
Dependabot does not currently support `versioning-strategy:
"increase-if-necessary"` for Cargo
(https://github.com/dependabot/dependabot-core/issues/4009) so I left
that out.

data.author: Eric Lujan
data.message:
Package foxglove_bridge in docker image (#600)

### Changelog
- [Foxglove Bridge] The public beta of Foxglove Bridge is now packaged
as a Docker image in our public image registry

### Docs
README.md for bridge updated with image pull instructions

### Description
Create GHA workflow for pushing a Docker image containing the Foxglove
Bridge to our public image registry. This is in response to customer
feedback that providing these images helps them more easily deploy
Foxglove Bridge.

Images are built against all currently supported versions of ROS. The
GHA workflow is currently configured to build the bridge:
- On a push to `main`, where the version identifier will be the git SHA
of the commit on `main`
- On an SDK release tag (i.e. `sdk/vxxx`), where the version identifier
will be the SDK version number

The version number of Foxglove Bridge is incremented to equal that of
Foxglove SDK, as per our consensus that the versioning/release cadence
of these components should be coupled going forward.

Fixes: FLE-1

data.author: Bryan Fox

Re-generate LocationFixes (#608)

This re-runs `generate` to update schemas. I hadn't merged latest main
into #556 before merging, and it missed a recent addition to the channel
interface from v0.11.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Add `LocationFixes` schema; color `LocationFix` (#556)

Add a new `LocationFixes` schema for visualizing a series of fixes on
the Map panel, and a `Color` field to `LocationFix`

This adds a `Color` field to `LocationFix` and adds a new
`LocationFixes` schema. `LocationFixes` contains an array of
`LocationFix` messages.

There are a couple of use cases driving this change:

- A system tracking multiple entity locations publishes a
`LocationFixes` message containing a location fix for each entity at a
given timestamp. Each location's color can be used to differentiate when
visualized.
- Render a history of locations (track). Each fix has its own timestamp.

This array schema is reminiscent of the `FrameTransforms` schema.

Alternatives considered: Instead of adding Color, assign some sort of
group ID to location fix, which would allow the app to determine a color
at render time.

Changelog

Sourced from strum's changelog.

0.27.2

  • #141: Adding support for doc comments on EnumDiscriminants generated type.

    • The doc comment will be copied from the variant on the type itself.

  • #435:allow discriminants on empty enum.

  • #443: Change enum table callbacks to FnMut.

  • #444: Add #[automatically_derived] to the impls by @â€‹dandedotdev in Peternator7/strum#444

    • This should make the linter less noisy with warnings in generated code.

  • #440: Implement a suffix attribute for serialization of enum variants.

    #[derive(strum::Display)]
#[strum(suffix=".json")]
#[strum(serialize_all="snake_case")]
enum StorageConfiguration {
  PostgresProvider,
  S3StorageProvider,
  AzureStorageProvider,
}

    fn main() {
let response = SurveyResponse::Other("It was good".into());
println!("Loading configuration from: {}",
StorageConfiguration::PostgresProvider);
// prints: Loaded Configuration from: postgres_provider.json
}

  • #446: Drop needless rustversion dependency.

data.author: Eric Lujan
data.message:
Use dedicated context in foxglove_bridge (#591)

### Changelog
None

### Docs
None

### Description
Bugfix PR to have the FoxgloveBridge's WebSocketServer use its own
context instead of the SDK's default context. This resolves issues in
benchmark tests when instantiating FoxgloveBridge in a tight loop using
the global context, where clients could receive messages enqueued by
previous iterations of the benchmark.

Fixes: FG-12700

build(deps): bump schemars from 0.9.0 to 1.0.4 (#575) [//]: # (dependabot-start) âš ï¸ **Dependabot is rebasing this PR** âš ï¸ Rebasing might not happen immediately, so don't worry if this takes some time. Note: if you make any changes to this PR yourself, they will take precedence over the rebase. --- [//]: # (dependabot-end) Bumps [schemars](https://github.com/GREsau/schemars) from 0.9.0 to 1.0.4.
Release notes

Sourced from schemars's releases.

v1.0.4

Fixed

  • Fix JsonSchema impl on atomic types being ignored on non-nightly compilers due to a buggy cfg check (GREsau/schemars#453)
  • Fix compatibility with minimal dependency versions, e.g. old(-ish) versions of syn (GREsau/schemars#450)
  • Fix derive for empty tuple variants (GREsau/schemars#455)

v1.0.3

Fixed

  • Fix compile error when a doc comment is set on both a transparent (or newtype) struct and its field (GREsau/schemars#446)
  • Fix json_schema!() macro compatibility when used from pre-2021 rust editions (GREsau/schemars#447)

v1.0.2

Fixed

  • Fix schema properties being incorrectly reordered during serialization (GREsau/schemars#444)

v1.0.1

Fixed

  • Deriving JsonSchema with no_std broken due to std::borrow::ToOwned trait not being in scope (GREsau/schemars#441)

v1.0.0

This is a major release with many additions, fixes and changes since 0.8 (but not many since 0.9). While the basic usage (deriving JsonSchema and using schema_for!() or SchemaGenerator) is mostly unchanged, you may wish to consult the migration guide which covers some of the most significant changes.

Changes since 1.0.0-rc.2:

Added

  • #[schemars(bound = ...)] attributes are now used from fields as well as containers
  • The Schema::pointer(...) method now works when given a JSON pointer in URI Fragment representation with a leading # character. In particular, this means that you can now lookup a schema from a $ref value using that method.

Fixed

  • Schema names that contain special characters are now correctly encoded when used inside a $ref value (GREsau/schemars#436)
  • Optimise type param usage in SchemaGenerator::subschema_for, reducing LLVM line count and improving compile times (GREsau/schemars#439)

v1.0.0-rc.2

Added

  • Serde attributes that you want schemars to ignore can now be "unset" by including them in a schemars attribute with a ! prefix, e.g. #[schemars(!from)] (GREsau/schemars#433 / GREsau/schemars#434)

Removed

  • âš ï¸ Deprecated items have been removed:
    • SchemaSettings::option_nullable and SchemaSettings::option_add_null_type fields
    • gen module

v1.0.0-rc.1

... (truncated)

Changelog

Sourced from schemars's changelog.

[1.0.4] - 2025-07-06

Fixed

  • Fix JsonSchema impl on atomic types being ignored on non-nightly compilers due to a buggy cfg check (GREsau/schemars#453)
  • Fix compatibility with minimal dependency versions, e.g. old(-ish) versions of syn (GREsau/schemars#450)
  • Fix derive for empty tuple variants (GREsau/schemars#455)

[1.0.3] - 2025-06-28

Fixed

  • Fix compile error when a doc comment is set on both a transparent (or newtype) struct and its field (GREsau/schemars#446)
  • Fix json_schema!() macro compatibility when used from pre-2021 rust editions (GREsau/schemars#447)

[1.0.2] - 2025-06-26

Fixed

  • Fix schema properties being incorrectly reordered during serialization (GREsau/schemars#444)

[1.0.1] - 2025-06-24

Fixed

  • Deriving JsonSchema with no_std broken due to std::borrow::ToOwned trait not being in scope (GREsau/schemars#441)

[1.0.0] - 2025-06-23

This is a major release with many additions, fixes and changes since 0.8 (but not many since 0.9). While the basic usage (deriving JsonSchema and using schema_for!() or SchemaGenerator) is mostly unchanged, you may wish to consult the migration guide which covers some of the most significant changes.

Changes since 1.0.0-rc.2:

Added

  • #[schemars(bound = ...)] attributes are now used from fields as well as containers
  • The Schema::pointer(...) method now works when given a JSON pointer in URI Fragment representation with a leading # character. In particular, this means that you can now lookup a schema from a $ref value using that method.

Fixed

  • Schema names that contain special characters are now correctly encoded when used inside a $ref value (GREsau/schemars#436)
  • Optimise type param usage in SchemaGenerator::subschema_for, reducing LLVM line count and improving compile times (GREsau/schemars#439)

[1.0.0-rc.2] - 2025-06-19

Added

  • Serde attributes that you want schemars to ignore can now be "unset" by including them in a schemars attribute with a ! prefix, e.g. #[schemars(!from)] (GREsau/schemars#433 / GREsau/schemars#434)

Removed

build(deps): bump actions/download-artifact from 4 to 5 (#573) Bumps [actions/download-artifact](https://github.com/actions/download-artifact) from 4 to 5.
Release notes

Sourced from actions/download-artifact's releases.

v5.0.0

What's Changed

  • Update README.md by @â€‹nebuk89 in actions/download-artifact#407
  • BREAKING fix: inconsistent path behavior for single artifact downloads by ID by @â€‹GrantBirki in actions/download-artifact#416

v5.0.0

ðŸš¨ Breaking Change

This release fixes an inconsistency in path behavior for single artifact downloads by ID. If you're downloading single artifacts by ID, the output path may change.

What Changed

Previously, single artifact downloads behaved differently depending on how you specified the artifact:

  • By name: name: my-artifact â†’ extracted to path/ (direct)
  • By ID: artifact-ids: 12345 â†’ extracted to path/my-artifact/ (nested)

Now both methods are consistent:

  • By name: name: my-artifact â†’ extracted to path/ (unchanged)
  • By ID: artifact-ids: 12345 â†’ extracted to path/ (fixed - now direct)

Migration Guide

âœ… No Action Needed If:
  • You download artifacts by name
  • You download multiple artifacts by ID
  • You already use merge-multiple: true as a workaround
âš ï¸ Action Required If:

You download single artifacts by ID and your workflows expect the nested directory structure.

Before v5 (nested structure):

- uses: actions/download-artifact@v4
  with:
    artifact-ids: 12345
    path: dist
# Files were in: dist/my-artifact/

Where my-artifact is the name of the artifact you previously uploaded

To maintain old behavior (if needed):

data.author: Eric Lujan
data.message:
Expose sink_id in channel logging functions (#567)

### Changelog
- [python] calls to `channel.log()` can now optionally specify a sink ID
to target message logging to a particular sink
- [c++] calls to `channel.log()` can now optionally specify a sink ID to
target message logging to a particular sink

### Docs
Docstrings for SDK documentation updated

### Description
Exposes an optional parameter for `log()` on channel bindings to target
logging messages to a specific sink. This is already being used
internally by `foxglove-bridge` to allow for selectively publishing
low-frequency/latched topics to late joining clients while avoiding
duplicate message delivery to already-connected clients.

Tests added to C++ server unit tests to test this behavior with an
actual WebSocket client connected in the test. I added a test to the
Python side to make sure that the parameter was wired through without
causing a runtime error. I held off on adding deeper behavior testing on
the Python side because it'd require a Python implementation of a
WebSocket client, and I wanted to keep the LoC count of this PR
tractable.

Fixes: FG-12408 FG-12405

data.message:
Generate Timestamp & Duration schemas (#391)

This adds `Duration` and `Timestamp` to `FoxgloveMessageSchema`
definitions (rather than treating them as primitives), so that we can
begin documenting them as such in FG-11348.

Message schemas are now documented as part of the SDK
(https://docs.foxglove.dev/docs/sdk/schemas), and this matches the
"Timestamp" terminology used there.

In some cases, our types use the name "Time" rather than "Timestamp".
That hasn't changed here; documentation will link to equivalent
reference implementations.

For the most part, the generated schemas are unchanged. However:

- JSONSchemas now include Timestamp and Duration
- for FlatBuffers, I removed the documented `sec` range which was
outside the range of int32.
- Some definitions now inherit the schema & field descriptions for the
time-related types

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Update cbindgen for generated types (#555)

This PR makes cbindgen config part of the `generate` script, so that all
generated types automatically have their types exposed correctly in the
C headers.

Today, when a developer adds a new schema, they'd have to manually add
this rename mapping to cbindgen.toml in addition to writing the
typescript definition. I considered improving the docs & error messaging
(#554) but I think we should just make this the purview of `generate`.

Any manual cbindgen config should now be added to the 'prelude' toml
file.

This also removes the full C++ build from the generate script in favor
of the C build; if something goes wrong after generation, CI will catch
the error during C++ builds as usual.

Added dependency: [smol-toml](https://www.npmjs.com/package/smol-toml)

Fix typo in CameraCalibration docs (#553)

This fixes a typo in the description of the CameraCalibration message.

This also updates the `generate` task to build the C++ project as well,
since that in turn generates a C header from the rust source. The
contributing docs say to run this in a container, so it shouldn't break
the workflow if tooling is missing on the host.

data.author: Eric Lujan
data.message:
Do not send deleted/non-existent params to clients (#545) ### Changelog - WebSocket server will no longer send non-existent or deleted parameters in its response body ### Docs None ### Description When publishing parameters to clients in response to get_parameter or set_parameter requests, or updates to subscribed parameters, filter out parameters with None values. This brings the SDK implementation in-line with the same observable behavior as [the previous ws-protocol implementation](https://github.com/foxglove/ws-protocol/blob/305d217eec5e38ff8d6b8e8b4f64d9d087193193/cpp/foxglove-websocket/include/foxglove/websocket/websocket_server.hpp#L882-L887). Part of the motivation here is that, according to [the protocol spec](https://github.com/foxglove/ws-protocol/blob/305d217eec5e38ff8d6b8e8b4f64d9d087193193/cpp/foxglove-websocket/include/foxglove/websocket/websocket_server.hpp#L882-L887): > If the value is not set (undefined), the parameter shall be unset (removed). I found that, if these values are not filtered out, and the WebSocket server sends them to the Foxglove app, they still show up in the Parameters panel with an empty value column instead of being fully deleted: After this change, the parameter is no longer present in the UI: ---- Today, this issue is unlikely to come up, because the app currently (1) occasionally polls get_parameters to determine which parameters exist and only requests those and (2) doesn't expose UI elements for deleting parameters. To demonstrate this issue, I had to modify the param_server example to manually publish an empty Parameter. But should either of these change, if we published empty parameter values, the frontend would exhibit unexpected behavior unless it was also modified to ignore parameters from the server with no `value` field. Alternatively, to avoid this issue without this change, users wanting to use the SDK WebSocketServer to provide parameter functionality would need to be careful in their `on_set_parameters` callback to monitor for deleted parameters and filter them out of the vector of parameters their callback returns. I felt that was also non-ideal and moving it into the SDK provides that safety for free. This PR also does some light refactoring to eliminate duplicate codepaths for publishing parameters to clients. All parameter publication logic now goes through `ConnectedClient::update_parameters()` to centralize any filtering/message modification we may wish to do in the future.
BeforeAfter
The SDK server will publish empty parameters in its JSON response Parameters without value fields are filtered out any time the server publishes them to a client

data.author: Eric Lujan
data.message:
Introduce explicit integer Parameter type (#542) ### Changelog - Introduce an explicit Integer (64-bit signed integer) type for Parameters. - Rename the Number parameter type to Float64 to make its semantic clearer - Update Rust/C/C++/Python bindings to allow constructing Integer and IntegerArray parameters, and to rename Number to Float64 for consistency. ### Docs Documentation comments updated. ### Description Previously, the Number parameter type was overloaded to represent both integer and floating-point types (this is because when parameters are sent over the wire as JSON, the distinction is lost). SDK users wanting to construct integer parameters needed to cast them to doubles. When these values were round-tripped through the WebSocketServer interface, a fractional part of `.0` was added, which caused some deserialization libraries to treat them as doubles. While this can be worked around by SDK users by rolling their own serialization and deserialization overloads to infer when a number should be cast to a native integer type or kept as a double, it's more ergonomic for the SDK to allow for constructing parameter values from native integer types, and to make a best-effort attempt to serialize integer parameters without adding a zero fractional part (ie. `"my_param": 42` over `"my_param": 42.0`). This PR also includes a custom JSON deserializer to more closely align the behavior of parsing params from the wire into the behavior in the protocol spec (namely, more closely respecting and enforcing checks around the `type` tag).
BeforeAfter
Only a Number parameter type exists, which handles both floating point and integer values. A new Integer parameter type exists for handling explicit integers. Number is deprecated and replaced with Float to be more explicit.
Fixes: FG-12407

data.message:

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
C++: use original `tl` namespace for expected (#543)

This updates `expected.hpp` to use the original `expected` header file
from https://github.com/TartanLlama/expected, to fix naming conflicts
when a project includes the same header. See #540.

Previously, when using our own namespace, we also conditionally (in
C++23) used `std::expected`. We can decide to re-introduce that later,
but for simplicity, let's use the header directly. I left the header in
the existing location, to avoid breaking any build setups (including
what we document in the quickstart).

To test this, I added the example here, which (at the first commit)
fails to build with the error described, but succeeds with the updated
header. I don't plan to merge this example; it's intended to help PR
review.

Fixes #540.
