data.author: Eric Lujan
data.message:
Thread through the client ID to the subscribe/unsubscribe callbacks for WebSocket server (#515) ### Changelog - Create a new function, `Channel::log_to_sink`, allowing users to optionally specify an individual Sink to target a logged message to. If left `None`, the message is logged to all sinks associated with the channel's context. - Update C++ bindings for `Channel::log` to take a sink ID as an optional argument. - Update C++ `WebSocketServerCallbacks::onSubscribe` and `WebSocketServerCallbacks::onUnsubscribe` function signatures to take `foxglove::ClientMetadata` as a second parameter, which surfaces information about which client and associated sinks are requesting to subscribe or unsubscribe to a channel. ### Docs Doxygen comments are updated. ### Description These changes are motivated by work to port `ros-foxglove-bridge` to use the SDK. The main problem being solved is ensuring that messages are delivered to late-joining clients. The ability to target `log()` calls to individual sinks gives WebSocketServer users more control over how messages should be delivered in this situation (i.e. by implementing logic that can republish a message to only a newly joining client without sending a duplicate to others). Surfacing information about which sink a given client is associated with allows sinks to be used as the semantic for targeting message logging, rather than coupling it to WebSocket client IDs. Unit tests pass. Added additional tests to verify that messages are only logged to the appropriate sinks if a target sink ID is passed.
BeforeAfter
All calls to `Channel::log` deliver messages to every sink associated with that channels's context. Calls to `Channel::log` can optionally be targeted to individual sinks.
Fixes: FG-12285

data.author: Bennett Hardwick
data.message:
Support adding channel and schema by id in data loaders (#525)

### Changelog

<!-- Write a one-sentence summary of the user-impacting change (API,
UI/UX, performance, etc) that could appear in a changelog. Write "None"
if there is no user-facing change -->

None

### Docs

None

<!-- Link to a Docs PR, tracking ticket in Linear, OR write "None" if no
documentation changes are needed. -->

### Description

When writing data loaders for formats like MCAP or db3, we already have
channel and schema IDs. This change allows authors to use those IDs
directly, instead of needing to look up by topic string or using some
other method.

It also fixes up schemaless channels, supports multiple channels with
the same topic name and adds some test coverage.

It also removes some other methods that might not be necessary.

data.author: Eric Lujan
data.message:
Fix race where on_subscribe callback is called before channel is registered with a context (#533)

### Changelog
None

### Docs
None

### Description
The Rust WebSocketServer implementation invokes its subscription
callback asynchronously before the connected client's sink is registered
with that channel in the context. This can cause channel::log() to be
called in a callback before the sink is ready to accept messages.

This was discovered when working on porting ros-foxglove-bridge to use
the SDK as its backend; unit tests for logging latched messages were
failing ~2-5% of the time because messages were being dropped.

Verified that these unit tests now pass reliably with a locally-built
SDK artifact.

Fixes: FG-12371

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
Don't unadvertise a channel if an error prevented it from being advertised (#520)

### Changelog

Fixed a bug where a channel that fails to be advertised to a websocket
client would still be unadvertised. Now unadvertise is only sent if
advertise succeeded for a channel.

### Docs

<!-- Link to a Docs PR, tracking ticket in Linear, OR write "None" if no
documentation changes are needed. -->

### Description


https://linear.app/foxglove/issue/FG-12137/sdk-websocket-server-should-not-unadvertise-channels-that-it-failed-to

I modified one of our tests to identify this issue and fail, then fixed
the bug and verified the test passes now.

Skip publishing data_loader for now (#522)

This turns off publishing for the foxglove_data_loader crate, since we
have not yet published it, to unblock the release process for SDK.
FG-12276 tracks the setup needed to publish this new crate.

data.message:
Introduce strict build and configure CI to use it (#509) ### Changelog None ### Docs None ### Description Enable a set of Clang and MSVC compiler warnings and set them to fail builds if the `STRICT` compilation flag is set. This flag is set `true` by default in containerized builds, including the ones that run as a pre-merge check in GitHub Actions. To disable these warnings, a user can run `make STRICT=false` from the `cpp/` directory. This PR also contains changes required to address the warnings in the existing SDK codebase.
BeforeAfter
Builds fail if compiler warnings are enabled and escalated to errors Builds pass with compiler warnings enabled
Fixes: FG-12163

This adds a C++ example using a custom protobuf type generated with
google's C++ protobuf library.

It's painful, I think we could improve this story a lot by moving the
boilerplate for the schema and channel creation and serialization into
the Foxglove SDK.

version.

container.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
ci: Don't do setup-rust-toolchain in python-linux builds (#489)

@eloff and I have both been bit by [inscrutable build failures in
CI](https://github.com/foxglove/foxglove-sdk/actions/runs/15645870788/job/44083140389),
where the jobs to build python linux wheels fail to find glibc. I'm
pretty sure that this is related to a bad caching strategy. I suspect
that if we drop the `setup-rust-toolchain` step from the job, it'll
prevent this problem from happening in the future.

We don't really benefit from that step anyway. The maturin-action takes
care of installing the rust toolchain. The comment about rustfmt is
stale; we used to do rust codegen as part of the python build, but
that's ancient history.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
C++: Support channel metadata (#479)

This adds support for channel metadata in C++. A user may supply
key/value pairs when constructing the channel.

The C library provides an iterator on top of the underlying BTreeMap,
which the C++ method uses to build up its own map. I expect metadata to
be typically small, and this getter to be called infrequently.

On the parameter order for `::create`: I added metadata last; I think it's possibly less common to use this than Context. If you want to supply metadata, but no Context, you have to provide the default `foxglove::Context()`. Longer-term, we could provide a builder interface around this if needed, but it was more than I wanted to tackle here.

I chose the generic struct name "FoxgloveKeyValue", thinking we might have other uses for that (e.g.,
supplying metadata for an MCAP file).

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Log struct with jsonschema & msgpack (#464)

This adds a C++ example which illustrates logging of custom data without
manual serialization.

The example sets up two channels; one with a json schema derived from
the struct, and one using [msgpack](https://msgpack.org/). The latter is
schemaless, but provides a binary option. The Foxglove app handles this
in the same way as schemaless JSON. A handful of messages are written to
an MCAP file. Both techniques rely on https://json.nlohmann.me/, which
is also used by the ws-services example.

This provides a couple of options for users who want to put together
logging of custom schemas quickly, without caring about the
serialization format. In python, we accomplish this by logging native
types (dict, etc); in rust, we provide derive macros for `Encode`, or
illustrate usage with `schemars::JsonSchema`.

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
C++ fix assertion crash copying zero-length vectors via the arena (#461)

### Changelog

Fix assertion failure in C++ when serializing empty vectors

### Description

arena.hpp:73: T *foxglove::Arena::alloc(size_t) [T =
foxglove_scene_entity_deletion]: Assertion `elements > 0' failed.

The problem was that arena alloc expects a non-zero allocation, but
arena map was calling it without checking the number of elements for 0
first. This checks and returns a nullptr for empty arrays. This means
they're passed to C as a nullptr with length 0, which fits with how we
represent empty arrays and strings.

While I was at it, I noticed that forward declaring context and errors
in mcap.hpp meant that you had to include both of those headers whenever
you import mcap.hpp, I changed this to match how we did channel.hpp and
server.hpp, which makes it a little more friendly to use.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
python: Add Message.get_schema() and various channel getters (#441)

This change add a `get_schema()` staticmethod for foxglove message
types, and plumbs various getter methods for channels:
- message_encoding
- schema
- metadata
- has_sinks

Since `message_encoding` was previously an instance attribute on
`Channel`, I decided to convert them to a instance property method for
compatibility reasons, even though it's not consistent with the instance
methods we use for topic(), id(), etc.

This change also derives the magic `eq` methods for the `Schema` class. 

It's a big change, but it's mostly codegen.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
codegen: Remove "Primitive" suffix filters (#442)

When we wrote `foxglove_proto_gen` back in the day, we excluded certain
kinds of codegen for schema types whose names end in "Primitive". The
choice was rather arbitrary, and it's been questioned a few times in
various contexts.

I finally bumped up against it while trying to plumb through a
`get_schema()` staticmethod for schema types in python, so I hereby
declare that it's time to drop the filter. If you want to create an
`ArrowPrimitive` channel, go for it. It's surely no stranger than a
`Color` channel.

data.author: Eloff
data.message:

Add an example of using the C++ typed channels, similar to the box and

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
Add note to docs that schema classes are immutable and don't provide getters and setters (#437)

Our implementation converts from Python types to Rust types eagerly in
the constructor. Stacking getters on top of that requires converting
back from Rust -> Python, and then a setter would do the conversion
again Python -> Rust. For types like strings, bytes, lists, nested
structs, lists of nested structs, each of these conversions requires
memory allocations and copying.

We didn't provide getters and setters to begin with because we wanted to
discourage inefficient usage.

I think the right way to do this is keep the data as Python types until
the call to log, and do the conversion inside the log method as a
temporary conversion and then discard the temporary before returning.
This is how I implemented the C++ conversion and serialization
efficiently. This would also let us do things like log a large byte
array without allocation and copying (e.g. from image, audio, and video
types.) Then getters and setters simply access the Python type and are
cheap and natural in Python, but I don't think we have time for that
now.

Given the above constraint, we can choose to provide the interface now,
but inefficiently, or we can keep the status quo and not facilitate the
API to be used in a way that will perform very poorly. I argue that we
should keep the status quo until we have the time to implement it
correctly. It will force users to write their code in a way that works
reasonably well today, and when we relax that constraint in the future,
it won't break existing code, but the API will get friendlier. At most
we could think of providing getters only now, keeping the schema classes
immutable. But the user could work around the lack of getters by
declaring intermediate variables and using those instead - which avoid
the additional Rust -> Python conversion.

I think we can just call this out clearly in the documentation now, and
that's what this PR does.

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
Add docs about thread-safety to C++ API (#432)

What it says on the tin.

Maybe I should also mention something about thread-safety in the
overview on the docs index?

I think we're also going to need thread-safety docs for Rust and Python.

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
Don't use default values from schemas for C++ (#436)

This removes the non-zero default values for C++ schemas to match Rust
and Python.

The reasoning:

There weren't many fields with a non-zero default value, and while w=1.0
makes sense for quarternion, the values make less sense for vectors and
colors.

Rust has default of 0 as defined by prost protobuf library, and we can't
change that, so if we use non-zero defaults elsewhere it won't be
consistent across the sdk.

Having everything default to 0, but a couple exceptions could be
surprising to developers.

We didn't document the defaults:
https://docs.foxglove.dev/docs/visualization/message-schemas/quaternion

Slack discussion:
https://foxglove.slack.com/archives/C07RB3SSJE5/p1747846188213449

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
Accept u64, Timestamp, SystemTime, and DateTime as log timestamps (#435)

Adds a new trait `ToUnixNanos` to unify the different kinds of
timestamps we can accept.
Adds a constructor `with_log_time` to `PartialMetadata` accepting an
impl `ToUnixNanos` arg
Adds a new log method `log_with_time` that calls `log_with_meta(msg,
PartialMetadata::with_log_time(timestamp))`
Modifies log! macro to accept any impl `ToUnixNanos` arg for log_time.

Discussion on the story here: FG-11537

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
Add foxglove schemas for C++ (#413)

This PR adds generated foxglove schema and channel types for C++. Tickets FG-11372 and FG-11373.

By having a dedicated channel type per schema type, we avoid the
overhead of dynamic dispatch (e.g. based on an enum with a giant switch
statement or virtual function table or similar).

It adds conversion code from C++ -> C. This may need to allocate in
cases where the C type has a different layout, so it also adds a
stack-based arena allocator used for those temporary allocations. The
arena is simply discarded when the function returns, as the converted
type doesn't outlive the function call.

The C -> Rust conversion code works the same way, but with lots of
unsafe code and ManuallyDrop to shoehorn borrowed data into owned types
without dropping it. Again a stack based arena is used (which is pinned
so it isn't accidentally moved). It should be possible to optimize this
in the future for types where the C layout of the protobuf struct could
be the same if we add repr(c) to it, we could avoid having to do this
conversion for those types (e.g. Color). The C++ code already does this
optimization, see isSameAsCType in generateSdkCpp.ts.

One gotcha is the Rust conversions can fail (e.g. invalid utf-8) so we
have to do all fallable conversions first, keeping the results inside
MnaullyDrop, before constructing the final ManuallyDrop<T> result.

We return the typed channel to C as a raw channel pointer, and then cast
it back to the appropriate typed channel in the log call.

The stack based allocators have a fixed buffer size of 128kb. They fall
back to heap allocation if they run out of space, tracking and freeing
the allocation when the arena is cleaned up. This seems extremely
unlikely as they're used only for small vectors and structs. I've
implemented many memory allocators in the past, but this is the first
time I've been able to include any in a PR at work!

The gist of this is we do some copying/transforming while other fields
are borrowed as-is (e.g. string, bytes, some vectors), but no heap
allocations and freeing on the logging path, apart from what is needed
to build the message schema object itself in C++.

I added a couple cherry-picked tests - it's not quite as good as
generating comprehensive tests, but this has dragged on for so long I
don't feel I have the luxury of time to do that.

Issue for more tests: FG-11383
Issue for example(s): FG-11374

https://github.com/foxglove/foxglove-sdk/pull/170, however there are

data.author: Roman Shtylman
data.message:
Add `foxglove::Encode` derive macro (#324)

### Changelog
Add a `foxglove::Encode` derive macro to implement the `Encode` trait
for logging custom structs using a binary serialization format.

### Docs
None

### Description
When using the Rust SDK to log data, one might want to define
app-specific structs for logging. The current recommended approach for
this directs the user to derive the `Serialize` and `JsonSchema` traits
for their struct. The foxglove SDK then provides a specialization of the
`Encode` trait for structs which have implemented these two other
traits.

```rust
#[derive(serde::Serialize, schemars::JsonSchema)]
struct Message {
    msg: String,
    count: u64,
}
```

This has some downsides:
- Field names are repeated in every message (leading to message size
bloat for smaller messages and high-rate data)
- "byte" fields are serialized as base64 strings
- No support for u64 (larger integers are not properly deserialized in
the app)

This change introduces a new `foxglove::Encode` derive macro. The
purpose of this macro is to implement the `Encode` trait for a struct
and thereby making it possible to log the struct on a channel.

The macro generates an implementation that serializes the
struct using the protobuf serialization format.

ci: Build rust examples individually (#419)

I noticed with #415 breaks the `example-mcap` build, but it isn't caught
in CI, because we're building the entire workspace all at once, which
means we're building dependencies with the union of all features
specified by all target packages.

This change adds a step to CI to build each example individually, to
ensure that we don't break them when we introduce new feature flags. We
only need to do this for examples, because we already build the other

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
C: Convince miri that FoxgloveStringBuf is safe (#416)

I was futzing with miri, to see if it could help us catch undefined
behavior in the C FFI. It seems fairly happy at the moment, though
I'd take that with a grain of salt, since our test coverage here is also
a little weak.

The one thing miri did notice is that the `FoxgloveStringBuf` was
casting a String to a const raw pointer, and then later casting to a
mutable raw pointer to recover it. This change helps miri to track the
pointer as a mutable reference.

C/C++: Add support for websocket parameters (#383)

### Description
This is _most_ of the work towards supporting parameters in C/C++.
Things that are here:

Part of: FG-10680

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Add shutdown handle for websocket server (#409)

### Changelog
- Breaking: rust: Add shutdown handle for websocket server

### Description
We need a way to wait for the websocket server to gracefully shutdown.
This is generally useful, but particularly important in C & C++ where we
need to ensure that there will be no future callbacks, so that we can
clean up resources.

This change accomplishes that goal by spawning client poll tasks within
a `JoinSet` on the server. When stop is called, we extract the `JoinSet`
into a `ShutdownHandle` and return it to the user. The user can choose
to wait for the tasks to complete, detach them to finish in the
background, or drop the handle to abort them immediately.

The C and python implementations now block waiting for the server to
shutdown gracefully.

C++: Provide an interface to set the level of SDK stderr logging (#405)

### Changelog
C++: Provide an interface to set the level of SDK stderr logging

### Description

This adds a C++ function to set the filter level for internal logging
from the SDK.

Naming: corresponds to python's `set_log_level`. I originally considered
including "severity" in the name to distinguish this from logging
messages onto channels. The term "severity" is used in Boost's 'trivial'
logging. Other alternatives considered: many permutations involving
"stderr", "filter", "min", "severity", and "level".

I added these to foxglove.hpp/cpp. I think it's reasonable to have share
some cross-cutting functionality in a single file, and I think we could
add "error" here. (I also considered putting this in errors.hpp since
they relate to stderr logging.) "config.hpp" is another option.

I also updated examples to make use of these as appropriate.

data.message:
C++: Fix deleted operator warnings for Channel (#406)

We can fix some pesky compiler warnings by defining a static deleter
for the Channel's `unique_ptr`. As a bonus, our `unique_ptr`s are now
half the size, since we don't need to store redundant pointers to the

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Document C++ interface (#407)

### Changelog
C++: Minor breaking: remove `testId` from Channel.

### Description

This adds documentation for the public C++ interface, and a doxygen
config file to allow generation of basic documentation. 2baef9 shows the
actual config file changes from the default generated file.

We're not locked in to using Doxygen; other tools support at least
subset of the syntax. I opted for "///"-style comments which is
familiar, and slightly easier to copy from Rust. Note one advantage of
using javadoc ("/**") or qt-style ("/*!") blocks is that Doxygen has an
"autobrief" config that lets us omit the `@brief` command.

I also removed `testId()` from channel, which was never called, and was
identical to `id()` regardless.

Future PRs will augment documentation and add generation & deployment
steps to CI.

This supports FG-11290.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
C++: Catch callback exceptions (#404)

If a user-provided callback in C++ raises an exception, that currently
causes an inscrutable panic in rust followed by a SIGABRT. Instead, we
should catch exceptions, log a message to stderr, and move on.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Add readability-identifier-naming rules (#392)

### Changelog
c++: Breaking: parameters such as mcap writer options are now snake_case

### Description

This fixes clang-tidy settings to include our C++ header files as well,
and fixes some of the resulting warnings.

This also adds `readability-identifier-naming` casing options to
clang-tidy, which accounts for most of the changes here.

The settings generally Google's style guide but use `camelBack` for
methods rather than initial caps. That's what we've favored so far; the
main change here, then, is to use snake_case for variables, etc. The
other change I added was to trailing underscore for private members;
since there are some specific restrictions related to leading
underscores, it seemed easier to enforce the latter.

The casing changes here do involve some breaking changes, and are up for
debate.

I omitted global options, since I don't see a reason for us to include
any.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Fix log! macro to reuse matching channels (#400)

### Changelog
- rust: Fix log! macro to reuse matching channels

### Description
Commit f6087cb7 introduced a bug, which caused the `log!` macro would
unconditionally create a channel per callsite. This change fixes that
bug, by properly deduplicating channels when they are added to the
context.

I decided to extend this deduplicating behavior to all channels. I can't
think of any reason for someone to deliberately create multiple channels
with precisely the same attributes, that differ only by ID. This should
have no impact for MCAP files, and can only improve the websocket
experience.

While working on this change, I realized that the context's topic index
actually needs to hold a list of matching channels, so that we can (a)
search for duplicates and (b) handle removal properly. I also realized
that `Context::add_channel` doesn't need to return a `Result`, since it
cannot fail. And in turn, the `panic!()` in the `log!()` macro is
actually unreachable!

Fixes: FG-11405
Fixes: f6087cb7

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
python: Expose logging context (#399)

This makes `Context` available to the python SDK, and adds an example
for usage. To use context from python, a user explicitly passes a
context to a channel constructor, and also to the `open_mcap` or
`start_server` functions. The "create_channel" method is private, at
least for now, because of the way typed channels are implemented in the
Python SDK.

This also cleans up the behavior of the untyped channel class to remove
the restriction on duplicate topics. This brings it in line with typed
channels and with Rust.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Rework websocket responder payload types (#395)

### Changelog
- rust: Breaking: Changed websocket FetchAsset and Service handler types

### Description
I originally proposed we use `bytes::Bytes` for websocket responders,
which works fine for callback wrappers that need to return an
owned/static value, but it's too restrictive for the underlying
responder methods, which would be perfectly happy with any `T:
AsRef<[u8]>`.

And so, the core of this change is updating
`service::Responder::respond` and `AssetResponder::respond` to
accept a `T: AsRef<[u8]>`.

Since that change breaks compatibility (albeit in a mild way), we might
as well go a bit further:
- If we accept an `E: Display`, we can simplify several callers.
- Callback wrappers can return a `T: AsRef<[u8]>`.

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
Add context to C and C++ (#364)

This adds a new C function to create a context and free a context.

It adds a C++ wrapper around the context, and provides a way to pass it
when creating channels, mcap writers, and websocket servers. It now uses
shared_ptr under the hood, so it can be trivially copied (like the
Arc<Context> in Rust).

The mcap and websocketserver use options structs in their creation, so I
added a Context to each options struct as a way to set the context. And
set that to a default, null context, which gets replaced by the global
context on the Rust side. Channels don't use an options struct, so I
added an overloaded constructor with 4 params where the final one is the
context, again defaulting to a null Context.

Then I updated all the tests to use a context scoped to the test so they
don't pollute the global context anymore (yay!)

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
python: Improved websocket parameters (#389)

### Changelog
- python: Improved websocket parameters

### Description
The purpose of this change is to make websocket parameters more
ergonomic in python, by implementing conversions to and from native
python types.

The basic idea is that we can infer the (type, value) from the type
information on a python object, so that the caller doesn't need to
specify it explicitly. Likewise, we can convert (type, value) back to a
single native python object using a `get_value()` method.

The implementation gets just a tiny bit hairy, because we need to
introduce some shim types to accomplish the conversions, but generally,
pyo3's trait system works in our favor.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Support channels with a shared topic (#385)

### Changelog

Do not error or panic if topic names are re-used between incompatible
channels.

Breaking: some rust interfaces have changed

### Description

This makes a few adjustments to our handling of re-used topic names
within a context's channels.

At a high level, there's a bit of a mismatch between the handling of
channels and topics in Foxglove and MCAP. MCAP doesn't dictate anything
here. The app doesn't have an explicit concept of a Channel; it instead
relies on topic names. There's a slight complicating factor in that the
Rust MCAP library has a notion of a "canonical channel"; if you create a
second channel with identical topic, schema, etc., then you'll get back
a reference to the canonical channel. It appears to be the only MCAP
library to behave this way.

The motivation here (and initial bug report) is to ease playback of MCAP
data which was created from other sources, which may contain multiple
channels with the same topic name. I tried to take a pragmatic approach
here that may err on the side of being too flexible. Instead of
returning an error (or panicking), SDK will log a warning that a
duplicate topic name was encountered, and I updated documentation to
clarify that topic names *should* be unique for compatibility.

With duplicate topics in play, this brings live viz from the SDK more in
line with MCAP playback (in terms of app behavior).

#### Considerations / future enhancements

We could introduce something like a "strict mode" (opt-in) which does
panic when encountering state that won't be fully compatible with the
app. That could arguably make initial development or testing easier when
app compatibility is the goal.

We could consider adopting the "canonical channel" behavior for the WS
Server as well, in order to coalesce channels that share a schema.
Currently, the app will only subscribe to one channel associated with a
topic. We could instead investigate enhancements in the app for
subscriptions to shared topic names (and the equivalent for file
playback).

I did consider keeping the behavior stricter for now. (I don't think
panicking should be the default behavior in these cases, but I'm less
convinced that these shouldn't be errors.) But I think the approach here
is more practical in the near term.

data.author: Miles Egan
data.message:
Fix generation of data fields in python class generation. (#375)

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
C/C++ error handling (#350)

Adds error returns and error details to the C APIs which can fail.

This is a rework of the error handling based on feedback from James.
Instead of returning error strings to C, we can return an error type
enum (which we just map directly from the enum members in FoxgloveError
in the crate root.)

The reason is we don't really need the full string errors. An error code
is enough, plus we log the full string message. The user can debug based
on the error code, and if that's not enough, enable the logs and check
them. It's not quite as convenient for debugging, but it's a lot more
convenient for library usage and we don't have to allocate and free
errors on the heap.

Additionally the C++ API was changed to modern C++ practice of using
Result-like return values instead of exceptions. This also means
constructors had to be replaced with static create methods instead, so
that it can return the result. For this I used tl::expected which is an
implementation of std::expected in C++ 23.
https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/expected

One annoying thing is our error enum is duplicated as a C enum and then
duplicated again as a c++ enum. A bit of a pain to update correctly, so
I opened a ticket to generate these instead so they don't get out of
sync.

I added some tests to exercise the error handling in the C++ API.

One change I made is to remove the foxglove_server_free and
foxglove_mcap_free functions, preferring to use just the stop/close
methods. There's nothing one can do with a closed/stopped server or mcap
writer, so there's no point separating stop/close from free.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
C/C++: Add artifacts to release assets (#369)

This makes the release artifacts from the C/C++ CI workflow available on
a draft release.

A draft release can't have assets with duplicate file names, so I zipped
the artifacts prior to uploading, which will preserve the original
library filenames once extracted. I put the shared & static libraries in
the same zip because it seemed a little easier to find what you're
looking for, but of course it increases the download size (particularly
for shared); we could produce a zip for each.

These changes produced [this v0.6.0
draft](https://github.com/foxglove/foxglove-sdk/releases/tag/untagged-29e1bf6fd156a0a64220).

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
python: fix channel interface to provide ID (#370)

This adds `id()` to the Python channel interface. We publish
subscription notifications on the server callback interface with these
IDs, but they were not meaningful until now.

This also updates the typed channel interface with public getters for
schema and topic name to match the raw channel getters added in #368.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Doc updates (#367)

This improves generated documentation and code comments in a few places:

- Remove the explicit "unstable" note from python docs
- resolves FG-10910: Add links to schema documentation to explain their
use in visualization
- resolves FG-10867: clarify the reason for renaming of GeoJSON

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
python: fix default schema names; provide topic and schema getters (#368)

This improves the handling of schema definitions which aren't given a
name. Previously, we defaulted to a hard-coded string. This produces
warnings in the app if you create multiple channels with unnamed
schemas. Now, we'll generate based on a hash of the schema contents so
that differing schemas will have different names, with reasonable
probability. I used base64 encoding and prefixed with "schema-" so that
labeling within the app is clear to users.

This also exposes `topic` and `schema_name` on the Channel, and improves
the serialized representation of the channel class.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
python: Fix library annotations (#366)

Setting `FOXGLOVE_SDK_LANGUAGE=python` works locally, but not in CI,
because `PyO3/maturin-action` runs the build inside a container, and
cherry-picks env vars.

We could poke our env var through using the action's `docker-options`
input, but I think it's more straightforward to call
`set_sdk_language("python")` from the module entrypoint.

This should also cover the case where someone decides they want to build
the python SDK bindings from the sdist.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
Batch websocket channel advertisements (#365)

When a websocket is established, we can advertise channels in batches,
rather than one at a time.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Remove WebSocketServerBlockingHandle (#362)

Follow-up from #360. We can now remove the
`WebSocketServerBlockingHandle` entirely, since there are no more async
methods on `WebSocketServerHandle`.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Finish splitting up websocket.rs (#363)

This is the capstone change to break up websocket.rs into more
manageable pieces. This change, despite its size, is purely code motion
and a sprinkling of `pub`s.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Remove publish_time and sequence from metadata options (#358)

This proposes to remove `publish_time` and `sequence` from `Metadata`,
which users can currently provide to `log()`.

### Motivation

#### Publish Time

`publish_time` is a message field in MCAP but does not have universal
support in the Foxglove app. Some panels do support this (e.g. plot),
but also support user-defined timestamp fields, where users are free to
define their semantics. Data imported to a Foxglove primary site is
ordered by log_time. The SDK should not include this only to support
writing to an MCAP field; the MCAP spec dictates that log_time should be
used if publish_time is unavailable.

#### Sequence

`sequence` is a message field in MCAP. It's useful for detecting
missing, out-of-order, or discontinuous messages. The existing
implementation is problematic because users are free to set sequence
numbers in some log calls, but not others, which would result in an
out-of-sequence stream with possible duplications. In ROS 2,
`std_msgs/Header` no longer includes a sequence
(https://design.ros2.org/articles/changes.html) because it was
inconsistent in ROS 1. Data streamed from a Foxglove primary site
produces its own sequence numbers.

### Notes

For the Rust SDK, where users work with metadata structs directly, I've
left `log_time` inside those structs. Arguably, it's less useful now
that there's only a single field â€”Â there's no longer a reason for
`::default`, and a future addition will likely mean manual changes for
those users. Still, I think the migration would be easier, and the
struct better communicates the intent.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
python: allow logging on schemaless channels (#349)

Python: 'schema' and 'message_encoding' are now both optional when
defining a channel.

One stated use case for the SDK is that a user should be able to log
messages for custom schemas without needing to care about the underlying
encoding or serialization. This enables faster development for
exploratory use cases, and makes it easier to test out ideas in the app.

In the Rust SDK, we support this use case by providing the `Encode`
trait for custom structs that implement
[JsonSchema](https://docs.rs/schemars/latest/schemars/trait.JsonSchema.html),
which can be used with typed channels. We've discussed doing something
similar in the Python SDK; perhaps annotations that allow us to
dynamically produce schemas with minimal effort from the user. However,
this feels less pythonic to me than allowing users to log dicts and
taking care of the encoding for them. We took a similar stance with the
"high-level" API â€” a user logs their data to [untyped] channels. The SDK
is already partway there; we support this behavior on channels if you
explicitly choose "json" encoding, or provide an "any object" schema.
And the app supports generally schemaless logging using JSON.

If we move forward with some Rust solution that allows logging of custom
schemas with binary protocols (#318), then we can consider something
like that for other languages as well.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Reject websocket clients after Server::stop (#361)

This fixes a bug in the websocket server, where the server may accept
new connections after `Server::stop()`, and fail to shut them down
properly.

The idea is to use `Server::clients` as the point of synchronization.
While stopping the server, we take the contents of that `CowVec` and
freeze it, so that new clients cannot be added. The concurrent accept
loop, if it is still running, may accept a connection, and the server
will handshake it, but then immediately shut it down after failing to
add it to `self.clients`.

This change also cancels the accept loop a little earlier, to reduce the
likelihood of a new connection being accepted once `Server::stop()` is
called. I also removed the compare_exchange on `self.started` - once a
server instance is stopped, it's stopped forever.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Add websocket connection poller (#360)

This should be the last step in separating the client from the server,
so they can move into different modules.

The idea is to encapsulate the poll loop, so that the server doesn't
need to care about its inner workings. It just calls an `async fn
Poller::run(self)` which consumes self and returns when the client
connection is closed.

While we're at it, we might as well move the whole `WebSocketStream`
into the poller, too. That way, we can easily ensure that the connection
is shutdown in the appropriate sequence - i.e., there are no races
between the poller's send loop and some external attempt to send a
close message. But to accomplish that, we need better signalling to
indicate _why_ the connection is being closed. For that, we introduce
a `ShutdownReason` enum and use a oneshot channel to deliver it
to the poll loop.

A surprising upshot of this rearrangement is that `Server::stop` is no
longer async, which has two big implications:
- We don't need `WebSocketBlockingHandle` anymore.
- We can implement `Drop` for `WebSocketServerHandle`, if we want to.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Use new ws protocol implementation (#355)

### Description
In this change, we switch over to using the new ws protocol
implementation. The change is fairly mechanical, and shouldn't introduce
any functional changes.

I used the opportunity to split a few things from `websocket::protocol`
into `websocket::X`. These are basically just newtypes and conversions.

The tests shrank in size, perform stricter validation, and I find them a
little more readable. Not quite the eye-watering result I was hoping
for, but I think it's still a reasonable improvement.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Minor doc cleanup (#353)

I spotted a few minor improvements we could make while looking at the
published 0.5.0 docs.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Add replacement ws protocol module (#343)

### Description
This is a rewrite of the `foxglove::websocket::protocol` module, with
the following aims:
- Zero-copy where it makes sense
- All messages should round-trip and have snapshot tests
- Tungstenite support should be loosely-coupled

This change is already _enormous_, so I'll update the foxglove crate in
a separate PR.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Fix build for --no-default-features (#354)

### Description
CI was building the whole workspace with `--no-default-features`, which
means that the build was picking up all the feature flags from the
examples when building the foxglove crate. This change fixes CI to build
the foxglove crate alone with the `--no-default-features` flag.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Refactor websocket connection graph management (#348)

### Description
This is another change towards separating the websocket server from the
connected client. Just as with parameters, we don't really need to
maintain state in two places, and the server is the natural location
because (a) the connection graph state is shared, and (b) the server
needs to track how many clients are subscribed in order to deliver
unsubscribe callbacks.

This change also fixes a bug: we weren't removing a client's graph
subscription on disconnect. I added unit test coverage for this case (c2
disconnects without sending unsubscribe).

It was convenient to move the list of subscribers into the
`ConnectionGraph` itself, so that it'd be under the server's mutex
without having to introduce a new struct. A little wasteful to have an
extra hashset in there, but it's not like this weird corner of the SDK
is going to get a lot of use anyway.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Refactor websocket parameter subscriptions (#345)

### Description
As part of splitting up websocket.rs, I'm trying to disentangle the
`Server` from the `ConnectedClient`. Parameter subscriptions are one
case where the client and server are accessing each others' internal
state (and locks!).

It looks like we can simplify this by just moving parameter subscription
management to the server as a `HashMap<String, HashSet<ClientId>>`. The
client can be basically stateless. I think this also makes it easier to
reason about the correctness of the listener callbacks, by keeping the
logic and state in a central location.

data.author: Foxglove
data.message: Release 'sdk/v0.5.0'

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Fail WS handshake if client doesn't request any subprotocol (#347)

### Changelog

Custom WebSocket clients of the SDK must ensure they're requesting
"foxglove.sdk.v1" in the "sec-websocket-protocol" header.

### Description

This updates/fixes the WS server handling of handshakes in the failure
cases. If a client doesn't request the supported subprotocol (or doesn't
include the protocol header at all), the upgrade fails and the
connection is closed with a 400.

Previously, we relied on well-behaved clients to close the connection
when their requested protocol wasn't supported, and we left the
connection open if the client didn't request any protocol.

Fix up python docs (#339)

This updates and fixes python documentation, and improves the sphinx
configuration for better cross-reference validation.

- Restore the `websocket` submodule documentation, as automodule is not

data.message:
Call `on_unsubscribe` when client disconnects (#338)

### Changelog

When a WS client disconnects, a server listener will receive an
`on_unsubscribe` event for all subscribed channels.

### Description

A Foxglove (WS) client may disconnect without explicitly unsubscribing;
a server listener should be made aware of this via the `on_unsubscribe`
callback.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Ensure feature-flagged items are documented (#344)

### Description
Turns out we need to provide docs.rs with configuration, if we want it to build
with --all-features so that non-default features get documented. Not so
surprising in retrospect.

Docs.rs generates docs with +nightly, which opens up features like
doc_auto_cfg, which is the handy thing that annotates feature-flagged
items as "available on crate feature <foo> only". To indicate that we're
running in a docs.rs-y environment, we pass `--cfg docsrs`. This idea is
lifted from tokio.

I also updated the CI script to run rustdoc with nightly and `--cfg
docsrs` so that we get coverage.

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
Add rust high level log! macro - type-safe logging without channels (#311)

Add channelless logging for rust via log! macro, similar to the Python log function.

The magic is in create_channel, which is called at most once for any
given log site. It creates the Channel or fetches an existing one from
the Context for the topic. It compares the schema and message_encoding
and panics if they differ, making it type-safe.

One catch is the Channel, once fetched or created, will live until the
end of the process. It can be added or removed from sinks or contexts,
but it can't ever be freed. It would be possible to provide a method to
free it, but I don't think that makes any sense.

The type of the log $msg for a given log site can't change in Rust
AFAIK. It's always the same type (even if that type were dynamic, e.g.
'Box<dyn Encode>' it's always a 'Box<dyn Encode>').

I added optional "named arguments" like keyword argument syntax in
Python for log_time, publish_time, sequence.

I didn't add a context argument, one because it would double the number
of cases in the macro, which are already many. But also because I think
it's not that useful. If you want to specify the context, it's better to
explicitly create the channel.

---------

Co-authored-by: Greg Smith <gasmith@foxglove.dev>

rust: Make Context public, add LazyContext (#335)

### Changelog
- rust: Add Context and LazyContext

### Description
This change unhides `Context` from the public API. The bulk of the
change is:
- Updating documentation to describe contexts.
- Add shortcut methods for building channels & sinks from a context.
- Add a `LazyContext` for use with `LazyChannel`.

Fixes: FG-10885
Fixes: FG-10854

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Set library version with SDK language (#288)

### Changelog

The SDK language is now reflected in the `library` written to MCAP
files, and is included in `serverInfo` metadata under the key
`fg-library`.

### Description

Example: `foxglove-sdk-python/v0.3.0`.

The language name is set at build time, based on environment. For C++,
which is a wrapper around the C library, a function is called by the log
sinks when they're created to override that language.

The app may use the serverInfo metadata for troubleshooting or
performance analysis. Foxglove has some precedent for the "fg-" prefix
in user agents and HTTP header keys. "fg-library" echoes the "library"
header of mcap.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Bump pyo3 & pyo3-log (#337)

This bumps pyo3 and pyo3-log to resolve the low-severity dependabot
alerts. pyo3 changes: https://github.com/PyO3/pyo3/releases. pyo3-log is
updated only to support pyo3 0.24.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Add Channel::close (#334)

### Changelog
- rust: Add `Channel::close`

### Description
As part of making `Context` public, I realized that we probably don't
want to expose `Context::remove_channel_for_topic()`. We should really
be removing channels by ID, to avoid TOCTOU errors. We should expose
this functionality publicly as `Channel::close()`, to mirror the python
`Channel.close`.

While I was doing that, I realized that [my fix for python's
`Channel.close`](https://github.com/foxglove/foxglove-sdk/pull/329)
should've also removed a lie in the docstrings ("Destroying all
references to the channel will also close it") and completely missed
updating the generated typed channels. So this change fakes care of
those things too.

The python SDK issues a (debug-level) warning when attempting to log on
a channel that was explicitly closed. In this change, we move that
warning down to rust, so that it's common. With a few changes:
- The message is now issued at _warning_ level, because we don't want
users to miss it.
 - Add a per-channel warning throttler with a 5s interval.
- Handle the case where a channel is implicitly closed because the
context is dropped.
 - Python no longer has to wrap channels in Option<>.

Fixes: FG-11010
Fixes: FG-10877

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Replace static_channel! with LazyChannel (#331)

### Changelog
- rust: Replace `static_channel!` with `LazyChannel`

### Description
This change attempts to address some of the feedback we've received
recently:
- `static_channel!` is weird, and merely obscures typing.
- Lazily-initialized channels are a footgun.

This change aims to address both concerns by introducing a new
`LazyChannel` struct. This removes the macro weirdness, and updates the
naming to make the laziness more overt.

Fixes: FG-10886
Fixes: FG-10913

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Set MSRV to 1.83.0 (#327)

### Changelog
- rust: Explicitly declare MSRV as 1.83.0

### Description
We currently use DebugTuple::finish_non_exhaustive,
which was introduced in rust 1.83.0. Explicitly declare that as the
MSRV, so that users get a nice error if their toolchain is too old.

If we wanted to support a lower MSRV, we could replace
`finish_non_exhaustive` with `finish` - it's not doing any heavy
lifting. If we do choose to do that, it looks like we can drop the MSRV
down to 1.80.0 (which is when `LazyLock` was stabilized).

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
Python: improve high-level log API  (#303)

Improves the Python `log(topic, message)` function:

Add more restrictive typings for the message, add a common base class
for all foxglove schema types (to better support the typings), add
support for dict, list, bytes, and str messages.

`dict | list` are serialized to json in a schemaless channel with
message_encoding='json'

`bytes | str` are serialized as-is, with str encoded to utf8 first

data.author: Bryan Fox

in introductory documentation on docs.foxglove.dev.

The rust & python examples log the same scene using typed channels. The
C++ example uses JSON. We may revise the python example in a future PR
depending on #303.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Fix websocket service schema encoding (#304)

### Description
When I implemented websocket services, I didn't know about the Service
Call panel in the UI, and so I did all my testing with a custom client
in rust. Turns out I botched the request/response schema encoding.

This change fixes the schema encoding, using the same logic that we use
for encoding channel schemas. The ws-services example is now compatible
with the UI.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Remove arbitrary sleeps from tests (#298)

### Description
Now that we have websocket clients represented as individual sinks, we
can remove a couple arbitrary 100ms sleeps from our tests, and instead
periodically poll the number of subscribed sinks on a channel.

While we're at it, we might as well get rid of some other arbitrary
sleeps as well, by polling on `RecordingServerListener` state, or simply
waiting to receive messages on the websocket client.

I ran tests in a loop on my machine for ten minutes and didn't see any
failures.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Manage websocket channel subscriptions dynamically (#293)

### Changelog
- Skip message serialization for a `TypedChannel` that has no subscribed
websocket clients.

### Description
This change makes use of the new subscription manager, to teach the
websocket to manage channel subscriptions dynamically based on client
demand. The websocket no longer automatically subscribes to all
channels. Instead, it only subscribes to channels that have one or more
subscribed clients.

To make that happen, we move the implementation of `Sink` from `Server`
to `ConnectedClient`. This is a bit simpler than the alternative, which
would involve maintaining an aggregation layer for propagating client
subscriptions back to the context. Anyway, it feels a bit more natural
to treat the clients as sinks.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
ci: Pin protoc to 5.29.3 (#301)

Pin CI to use the same version that we currently have locked
for `foxglove-schemas-protobuf`.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Use subscription manager (#292)

### Changelog
- Skip message serialization for a `TypedChannel` that has no sinks.
- rust: Add `Channel::has_sinks` and `TypedChannel::has_sinks`.
- rust: Hide `Sink` trait for now.

### Description
This change enhances the old channel->sinks linkage with the new
subscription manager.

Structural changes:
- `Context` is now an `RwLock` wrapper around an inner struct.
  - Most updates impact multiple resources.
  - Difficult to reason about sequencing and raciness.
  - The lock should be mostly uncontended.
- `ContextInner`:
- Holds a `Subscriptions` instance, which it uses to update channel
sinks.
  - Indexes sinks by `SinkId`, instead of by `Arc` pointer.
- Indexes channels by `ChannelId` in addition to topic, to support
(un)subscribe-by-id.
- `Channel` no longer implements `Drop`; its lifecycle is managed by the
`Context`.
- `LogSinkSet` is now an `ArcSwap` instead of `RwLock`, since we always
replace the entire vec.
- `Sink::auto_subscribe()` method indicates whether a sink subscribes to
all channels, default true.
- `Sink::add_channel()` now returns `bool`, for a dynamic subscriber to
add a subscription synchronously.
- `TypedChannel` queries for subscribers before serialization.

For now, the `websocket::Server` sink still auto-subscribes to all
channels. The next PR in this series will switch to using dynamic
registration.

Part of: FG-10743

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Add subscription manager (#281)

### Changelog
None

### Description
This change adds a new type for tracking subscriptions of sinks to
channels, but doesn't make use of it yet. That will come in a later PR.

We're planning to support two kinds of subscriptions: static
subscriptions to all channels (e.g., for mcap), and dynamic
subscriptions to particular channels (e.g., for websockets). We maintain
these subscriptions as two separate sets. When subscriptions change, the
`Context` will be responsible for querying the subscription manager in
order to regenerate the `LogSinkSet` for affected channels.

Part of: FG-10743

Support schemaless channels over websocket (#283)

This adds support for live visualization of JSON channels which don't
define a schema. Currently, the SDK requires a schema to be defined for
a websocket sink. A user can specify an empty schema, but that's a step
we shouldn't require them to take.

The ws server will behave the same for schemaless channels using message

build a channel within a context, but we don't have a nice way to tell
Sink builders (like `McapWriter` and `WebSocketServer`) to bind to a
context. Do that plumbing, and fix the corresponding tests.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Add SinkId for identifying sinks (#290)

### Changelog
- rust: Add `SinkId` and new mandatory `Sink::id()` trait method.

### Description
We've been using Arc pointers to compare log sinks, which isâ€¦ fine. But
it'd be a bit nicer if we just had a SinkId to use, like we have a
ChannelId. That would give us a natural way of indexing sinks, which
will be useful for both sink deregistration as well as subscription
management.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Wrap Context in Arc<> (#280)

### Description
We're going to need to store references to the `Context` on both
channels (for access to subscriptions) and sinks (for dynamic
subscription management and unregister-on-drop), so we're going to want
an `Arc`. Since the context holds `Arc` references to channels and
sinks, channels and sinks will hold `Weak` references back to the
context.

data.author: Jacob Bandes-Storch
data.message:
Change ClientChannel schema data to binary; unify base64 handling (#285)

### Changelog
None

### Docs

None

### Description

The current websocket protocol uses JSON messages for advertisements (in
both directions), which requires binary schemas to be base64-encoded.
Currently the SDK handles base64-encoding when sending `protobuf`
schemas to the client (although we missed also doing this for
`flatbuffer` schemas), but ClientAdvertisements left the base64 handling
up to the user (they would just receive a String which may or may not be
base64-encoded). This PR adds base64 handling for the client
advertisements as well so the SDK handles both directions and doesn't
require the user to mess with base64.

- Changed `ClientChannel.schema` to `Option<Vec<u8>>`
- Added `JsonClientChannel` & `JsonClientAdvertise` types for
deserialization, and `ClientChannel::try_from(JsonClientChannel)` to do
the base64 decoding
- Treat `flatbuffer` as base64 as well as protobuf
([docs](https://docs.foxglove.dev/docs/connecting-to-data/frameworks/custom))

now receive a `client_channel_id` instead of a `ChannelView`.

None

Motivation: all the information about the client channel should be
accessible to users in the callbacks.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
python: update & fix examples (#278)

This updates and, in places, fixes the python examples.

- Remove lock files
- Add a CI job to run all examples
- Fix some issues uncovered by the above (typing in python 3.9; renamed
class)

This also updates node in other CI jobs for consistency; v18 will be EOL
soon.

Once the API has stabilized, I would like to reference published SDK
versions with flexible constraints. This will make them easier to run,
since the current setup requires a rust toolchain. Having a CI step in
place will make sure examples continue to run correctly as we publish
new versions.

The new CI job is intended to catch basic errors in the python examples.
Because many of the examples run a live server indefinitely, these run
for 5s and then exit. I put the script at the top-level since we have
scripts there already, and because I don't want to clutter the examples
directory with auxiliary stuff. These also run sequentially as noted,
because I don't want to update examples to serve this CI step; I don't
think it'll be the bottleneck yet. There's room for improvement down the
line.

data.author: Jacob Bandes-Storch
data.message:
C/C++: run sanitizers in CI (#282)

### Changelog
None

### Docs

None

### Description

Resolves FG-10685

Runs tests under ASan+UBSan, ~TSan~, ~~and MSan~~. (ASan, TSan, and MSan
are mutually exclusive)

- Turns out the Memory Sanitizer is known to have issues/false positives
unless you compile _everything_ with it enabled, including the c++
standard library, so I excluded it.
- Turns out the Thread Sanitizer raises some false (or at least
annoying, non-actionable) warnings in tokio code, and I can't figure out
how to selectively disable those, so I excluded it as well.

Sanitizers can be run manually with e.g. `make SANITIZE=thread test`

data.message:
rust: Use Bytes instead of Vec<u8> in protobufs (#272)

For bytes fields on protobufs, we should use `Bytes` instead of
`Vec<u8>`. This enables zero-copy for buffers that are already `Bytes`
of course, but also for types `T: AsRef<[u8]> + Send + 'static` (via
`Bytes::from_owner`), such as you'd find for an `Arc<Vec<u8>>` or
`Mmap` or other various memory views.

data.message:
python: Don't override message_schema for json schemas (#271)

I watched @amacneil today as he did this:

```python
chan = Channel("topic", message_encoding="msgpack", schema={ ... })
```

That doesn't work as expected, because we automatically override the
message_encoding to be json when you provide a schema that looks like a
dict jsonschema. Which is a silly thing to do, in retrospect. The schema
encoding does not imply a message encoding.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
python: support asset serving (#259)

This adds support for an asset handler in the Python SDK. It follows the
general approach of services: we expect a single function that returns
the `bytes` of the asset, and call this function in a separate thread.

I also renamed "Request" -> "ServiceRequest" here. Even though the asset
request is only a single URI, I think this clarifies what the request is
for. It also localizes classes in the documentation.

I added a basic example which will serve "package://" assets from the
local directory. We could include URDF descriptions in the example
itself to make this easier to see out of the box; I haven't done so yet.

---------

Co-authored-by: Jacob Bandes-Storch <jacob@foxglove.dev>

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
Disconnect slow client when control plane fills up (#261)

There are two queues per connected client. One for data (log messages,
sent with channel.log) with is lossy. When it's full, we drop the oldest
queued message. But this doesn't work well for "control" messages where
missing a message would be bad, like channel
advertisements/unadvertisements, RPC responses, etc. So we have a second
queue for these messages that isn't lossy.

But we still have to do *something* when the control plane queue fills
up. If it's unbounded we consume resources until we crash the process.
If it's bounded, but blocking, then slow clients can block other clients
from making progress.

So we need to do something without blocking and without increasing the
queue size. The only thing that really makes any sense is disconnect the
slow client. It's obviously not a good experience for that client, but
we have to protect the process and the other clients. So we make this a
configurable message backlog size, and the if the user is getting
disconnected, and they have the resources to burn, they can increase it.
Conversely if the process is crashing with OOM they can decrease it.

To keep things simple there's just one configurable backlog size, and we
use the same value for the data plane and control plane queues. They
don't need to be the same size, but I'm not sure we need to expose two
adjustable backlog sizes for the user. By default we use a backlog of
1024 messages.

When we disconnect the client, we tell them why with an error status
message, and point them at the configurable backlog option.

---------

Co-authored-by: Copilot <175728472+Copilot@users.noreply.github.com>

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
Rust ws server asset protocol (#229)

This introduces another callback on ServerListener:

```
fn on_fetch_asset(&self, _uri: String, _responder: AssetResponder) {}
```

Where the AssetResponder has two methods

```
pub fn send_error(&self, error: &str)
pub fn send_data(&self, asset: &[u8])
```

And a public Client property. Alternately this could be private and we
could pass the client as the first argument like the other callbacks. I
don't feel strongly about which is better.

I added an example showing how to implement an asset server, although it
doesn't show how the client would work. Not sure if I should add a
client as well?

I also added a way to send status messages to a specific client on
Client, because callbacks in general lack a way to give feedback about
errors or warnings.

```
pub fn send_status(&self, status: Status)
```

Which mirrors publish_status on the server handle.

---------

Co-authored-by: Greg Smith <gasmith@foxglove.dev>

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
python: add close method to channels (#250)

Allow python implementations to explicitly close their channels, in
order to stop advertisements to the app.

For both typed channels and BaseChannel, each python class stores the
reference to the underlying channel as an option, and sets it to None
when closed. Calling `log` after this results in debug logging, but does
not raise an error.

I have not added this to any examples; I think this is a niche
requirement which is not typically needed.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Improve service handler wrappers (#249)

Borrow some good ideas for wrapping callbacks from @eloff's asset
handler work in #229.

In particular, I love the idea of handling the `tokio::spawn` and
`tokio::task::spawn_blocking` on our side, because it handles the 99%
case beautifully. Folks that want even finer control can always
implement `Handler` themselves.

Changes here:
- Remove `handler_fn` (which took `(Request, Responder)` as arguments).
- Rename `sync_handler_fn` as `handler_fn`.
- Add `blocking_handler_fn` and `async_handler_fn` for blocking and
async function handlers.
- Remove some useless `'static` bounds.

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
Rust ws server connection graph support (#237)

Adds support for connection graphs to the websocket server. This follows
the design in the C++ ws-protocol server very closely.

Clients can subscribe to updates, which sends the full state of the
connection graph in response. [This is not
documented](https://github.com/foxglove/ws-protocol/blob/main/docs/spec.md#subscribe-connection-graph-updates)
, I think we should update the spec to document that, as it doesn't seem
to me like it would work without it. The [C++ server behaves this
way](https://github.com/foxglove/ws-protocol/blob/main/cpp/foxglove-websocket/include/foxglove/websocket/websocket_server.hpp#L1449).

Like with parameters, we trigger callbacks on the first subscriber and
last unsubscriber to save the user having to do their own bookkeeping.
We tell them when they need to start being concerned with the connection
graph, and when they can stop.

It adds a method to the server, and the server handles for updating a
connection graph. One passes a new, full connection graph in, and it
will compute the difference with the last known state and send that
difference to subscribers. Because it works with differences, that's why
we need to send the full state when a subscriber first subscribes to the
connection graph.

The idea is the client will probably maintain a ConnectionGraph object
in the ServerListener that tracks the current graph, and after updating
it will clone() it and pass it to publish_connection_graph. The server
holds onto that copy so it can compute the diff the next time
publish_connection_graph is called.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Wrap Duration and Timestamp schemas (#247)

This change provides a new wrapper implementation for the `Duration` and
`Timestamp` types, to align with the foxglove schemas for those things.

- Use `sec` and `nsec` as field names.
- Infallible translation into `prost_types` equivalents for serialization.
- Offer (feature-flagged) conversions from chrono types.
- Update python bindings.

Note that all of the "convenience" conversion traits (from `std::time`
and `chrono` types) are fallible, because the foxglove schema is more a
restrictive representation in each case. Unfortunately, this means folks
are writing `ts.try_into().unwrap()` instead of `ts.into()`. To cope
with that, we offer `SaturatingFrom` and `SaturatingInto` traits, which
allows users to opt-in to an infallible conversion with clearly-defined
behavior.

This change does not attempt to provide conversions for python types.
We'll deal with that in a future change.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Update python logging handling and level support (#243)

### Changelog

- Python: logging is no longer configured automatically on import, and
defaults to `INFO`
- Python: `verbose_on` has been renamed to `set_log_level` and accepts
the same argument values as `logging.setLevel()`

### Description

The primary change here is that `logging.basicConfig` is no longer
called at the top-level of the foxglove module. This call is a no-op
once logging is configured, and our library should not risk configuring
logging unexpectedly. I considered going further and removing the call
entirely, but I do think it's convenient for some use cases, and users
are unlikely to be tripped up by configuration conflicts.

Other changes:

- `set_log_level` (renamed) accepts any of the standard `logging` level
values, including `logging.INFO`, `"INFO"` and custom levels; it no
longer accepts not our custom strings (including `"info"`). It no longer
raises assertion errors, but `logging` will raise value errors given an
unknown string.
- python logging defaults to "INFO", like rust

The examples that called `verbose_on` now do so with `DEBUG`.

Resolves FG-10629

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Don't expose websocket service IDs (#242)

Websocket service IDs are an implementation detail to accommodate
`ws-protocol`. It's not something that our users need to be aware of.
Service names need to be unique, and so that should be the handle by
which a service is identified or removed. I realized this as I was
trying to implement the python plumbing for `remove_services`.

Now we need two maps for indexing services: one by name, one by ID. They
need to be synchronized, so I introduced a new `ServiceMap` struct.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust, python: Pass client ID for service callback in Request (#244)

From discussion on #239:
Let's not pass around a separate `Client` to service callbacks. Instead,
make client metadata accessible on the `Request`.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
python: Add support for websocket services (#239)

This adds support for ws services to the Python SDK.

See #230 for a more detailed explanation. The main difference between
that PR and this one, is that this PR uses `tokio::task::spawn_blocking`
to invoke service callbacks, and reworks the callback interface to more
closely resemble the rust interface (a unified `Request` object instead
of its individual components).

---------

Co-authored-by: Bryan Fox <bryan@foxglove.dev>

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
python: implement additional ServerListener callbacks (#240)

This adds additional callbacks to python's ServerListener interface:
`on_subscribe`, `on_unsubscribe`, `on_client_advertise`, and
`on_client_unadvertise`.

I've updated the live_visualization example to monitor subscribers. This
example has been moved to `foxglove-sdk-examples`.

I did not introduce a new "channel view" type for python; there, the ID
types are identical. I don't see much value in a type that differs in
name only; I think the context makes it clear.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Support parameter subscriptions (#238)

This builds on #231 to add parameter subscription support to the Python
SDK. The SDK takes care of all bookkeeping and this is purely
informational for an implementer.

This also removes "parametersSubscribe" from the public SDK. Because the
SDK manages the subscriptions itself, as long as the client advertises
the "parameters" capability, the SDK will automatically include the
former capability. This does mean that the server listener callbacks
would be called regardless, but both languages provide default no-op
implementations.

As it says on the tin.

python: implement parameters on server listener (#231)

This adds `on_get_parameters` and `on_set_parameters` to the python
server listener, along with an example.

I think we'll eventually want a higher-level interface in Python for
this too â€” dealing with 'type' classes is not ergonomic â€” but having a
consistent interface seems valuable as well.

The core of this change is:
- Only one function to open an MCAP file: `open_mcap`.
- Create new by default, with an `allow_overwrite` kwarg.
- Implement context manager on `MCAPWriter`.

Other changes here:
- Use `PathBuf`, which pyo3 can construct from `str|pathlib.Path`.
- Fix up a bunch of sphinx cross references. Tested with #228.
- Add some test coverage.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
python: support status publishing on server (#227)

This adds `publish_status` and `remove_status` to the Python server
interface, to match the Rust SDK.

I've also updated the existing server methods to not raise exceptions,
since the Rust SDK doesn't return resuts. Currently, the only way for
these to fail is if the server has been shut down.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
python: Add a server listener that handles client message callbacks (#226)

This adds a server listener interface to the Python SDK.

This is implemented as a Protocol in python; pyo3 does not support
extending a Python class. To provide reasonable typing on
`start_server`, that's now a wrapping function in the public package, to
avoid the stub interface referencing the external type.

Since the ws-related code is starting to grow in python, I've moved
related classes and functions into `websocket_server.rs` (from lib.rs).
The exports are still in the top-level `foxglove` package for now.

To support the message data callback, this also adds support for the
`ClientPublish` capability and `supported_encodings`.

I updated the existing live_visualization example to exercise this.

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
rust: Support the rest of parameter protocol (#212)

This fills out support for the remainder of the parameter protocol.

I tried to follow the behavior of the Python server, with the exception
of the bug I uncovered, which is fixed here. on_parameters_subscribe and
on_parameters_unsubscribe is only called when a parameter is first
subscribed to by a client, or last unsubscribed to. This corresponds to
when you first need to worry about it, and when you can stop worrying
about it, without having to do that bookkeeping yourself.

Something I copied, but am unsure of, is how set_parameters will not
update parameters if there's no listener installed for the server.
Should that be the behavior?

Marked as a draft because I still need to add tests.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
python: broadcast time to clients (#224)

This adds support for broadcasting time messages to live clients. The
name and signature match Rust.

To support this, the package now exposes a `Capability` enum (currently
only containing "time").

I (roughly) ported the mcap playback example from the Rust SDK. The new
example is in a `foxglove-sdk-examples` directory outside of the SDK
directory, which more closely resembles our Rust example structure. See
#199 for motivation. If we like this structure, we can move the other
examples in a future PR.

I also made the `start_server` parameters keyword-only.

data.author: Adrian Macneil
data.message:
ci: Merge release tags with --ff when available (#225)

### Changelog
None

### Docs
None

### Description
When merging release tags, there is no need for `--no-ff`. The thing we
want to avoid is a squash merge (which would alter the commit we
tagged). But if there have been no new commits to main since the release
is tagged, then `--ff` is fine.

By removing `--no-ff`, git will automatically create either a
fast-forward merge or a merge commit, as needed.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Add support for websocket services (#213)

This change adds support for hosting custom services on the websocket
server. As far as I can tell, this is mostly intended to support the
ros-foxglove-bridge.

This turned into a pretty large change, but I'm not sure that splitting
it up into advertisement vs. call and response (as the linear tickets
are arranged) would've made things any easier.

The basic ideas:
 - Add the `Service` type (id, name, schema, handler).
 - Store an <Id, Service> map on the websocket server.
 - Provision a buffered response channel for each client.
 - Advertise and unadvertise services as necessary.
 - Handle calls:
   - Allocate a response (or reject with "too many requests")
   - Lookup service by ID (or reject with "unknown service")
   - Invoke handler.

The handler itself is a flexible trait, so that it can be as simple as a
`Fn` closure, or as complex as you like. At the moment, the handler runs
synchronously from the context of the client poll loop, but you can
always `tokio::spawn` your way to a less-constrained environment.

While writing tests (and the perhaps-overblown example), I realized that
I really _really_ wanted a full-featured crate for round-tripping
ws-protocol messages. I think we might want to pull
`websocket::protocol` out into its own `foxglove-ws-protocol` crate. Any
objections?

And because it's a bit buried, you can check out the service
registration demo
[here](https://github.com/foxglove/foxglove-sdk/pull/213/files#diff-2dc63a716bbefb10ba159933f2a1d3efec9caa0c5cde4bac7b39073ec726d81bR24-R72).

Fixes: FG-9672
Fixes: FG-9674

---------

Co-authored-by: Eloff <dan.eloff@gmail.com>

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
rust: inline definitions for derived schemas (#222)

This updates the auto-generated JSON schema for custom types to inline
definitions, rather than including `$ref`s. Current versions of Foxglove
do not support the latter.

This specifies the `draft07` version of JSONSchema, which is currently
the default in schemars.

I added an enum to the example to confirm that this works (does not
produce a 'problem') in the app.

data.author: Bryan Fox

We're currently using Sphinx v7 as v8 requires a newer version of

The docs are not yet deployed anywhere but can be built from the
