data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Downgrade some logging to debug (#221)

This reduces default logging noise by changing advertisements &
subscriptions to `debug`.

I added a more general "server started" info log, and made the tokio
runtime messaging debug. I think we could consider not logging anything
about "tokio" from the core SDK, but it also seems OK at debug level.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Update Python example and remove explicit encoders (#216)

This updates the Python example and underlying module to better
represent where we're headed.

The logging API serves the three use cases below.

1. Custom schemas and serialization.
2. Custom schemas, where the SDK serializes for you. 
3. Messages well-known Foxglove schemas.

This PR adds an example for use case (1), using JSON. I think we could
add an example using protobuf, but I don't want to add protobuf again as
a dev dependency. We could consider organizing examples like we've done
with Rust â€” each getting its own package.

Previously, the examples made use of provided `Encoder`s. This sort-of
addresses use case (2), but for JSON still required users to provide a
JSON schema. We plan to address this in a better way (FG-10466).

Use case (2) is already represented by the examples, and is unchanged
here.

However, for discussion: I've also kept it easy to work with JSON â€”
particularly for exploratory use cases. You can pass schemas and
messages as dicts, and these will be treated as JSON.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Update MCAP handling in Python SDK (#219)

This fixes the implementation of `PyMcapWriter` to agree with the
declared interface. Notably, it exposes the `close` method and documents
the auto-closing behavior if a reference to the writer is not held.

To make this easier to work with, this also adds a context-managed
function `new_mcap_file`, which frees the user from needing to maintain
a reference to the writer. I included 'mcap' in the name since (a) we've
decided to expose that name in the Rust SDK, and (b) it makes clear with
the output format will be, since we're asking the user to supply a file
name.

This also updates the example to produce a basic MCAP file.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Optimize serialization of byte buffers in Python SDK (#218)

This PR modifies the generated schema structs to improve the
serialization of byte arrays. When a struct `Vec` field is constructed,
pyo3 will iterate the vec and copy each element. This change updates the
`Vec<u8>` fields to accept a python-native type, from which we copy the
bytes at once. This doesn't require changing the protobuf interface in
the Rust SDK. There may be further optimizations we can make, but this
is pretty low-hanging fruit.

This also adds a point cloud channel to the live viz example, taken from
the linked blog post.

Earlier profiling showed that this approach (similar code) gave a
speedup of ~2. Writing 1000-pt point clouds in a tight loop to an mcap
file increases the publishing throughput 2-3x:

Before:

```
duration:  1.333925s
start:     2025-02-14T08:57:23.15778-05:00 (1739541443.157780000)
end:       2025-02-14T08:57:24.491705-05:00 (1739541444.491705000)
compression:
	zstd: [21/21 chunks] [15.37 MiB/1.85 MiB (87.94%)] [1.39 MiB/sec]
channels:
	(1) /pointcloud  1001 msgs (750.42 Hz)   : foxglove.PointCloud [protobuf]
channels: 1
```

After:

```
duration:  462.919ms
start:     2025-02-14T08:56:45.933291-05:00 (1739541405.933291000)
end:       2025-02-14T08:56:46.39621-05:00 (1739541406.396210000)
compression:
	zstd: [21/21 chunks] [15.37 MiB/1.52 MiB (90.09%)] [3.29 MiB/sec]
channels:
	(1) /pointcloud  1001 msgs (2162.37 Hz)   : foxglove.PointCloud [protobuf]
```

data.message:
Improve Python documentation (#217)

This PR improves the documentation of the Python SDK.

Runtime improvements:

- Sets the module name on `pyclass`es, which sets `__module__`
+ This fixes the printed representation (e.g., `<class
'foxglove.schemas.Color'>` instead of `<class 'builtins.Color'>`)

generated module
- Provides `__repr__` for schema and channel instances (e.g.

`TypedChannel` in core.

Other changes:

- Moves developer docs to CONTRIBUTING, and add more information to
README (based on the Rust readme)
- Creates some initial standalone documentation using Sphinx
    - Loosely based on the Rust readme
- Renames `examples/ws-demo.py` to `examples/live_visualization.py`

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Add ws-stream-mcap example (#196)

To play with the time messages, I wrote a little example to stream mcap
files over a websocket. Might also be useful for performance testing against

To use:

$ cargo run -p example-ws-stream-mcap -- --file path/to/recording.mcap

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Python SDK: integrate new channels and schemas (#210)

This PR integrates the new generated Schema and typed Channel classes
from #201 and #206 respectively, and updates the examples accordingly.

As part of this, I've adjusted the Schema classes to make them easier to
work with:
- fields are now `Optional`, with defaults. Callers can omit any
properties during construction.
- constructors are keyword-only, which should be more future-proof.

The protobuf dependency is no longer needed in the Python SDK.

For discussion: I've also re-worked the high-level API a bit. It works
with any given foxglove Schema now (though could use better typing). But
it no longer works with arbitrary protobuf messages. We could support
that, but I'm not sure how valuable it is. We could support arbitrarily
serialized data, but then you'd need to provide your schema, and the
channel interface seems much nicer.

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Generate pyo3 classes for channels in SDK (#206)

This builds on #201 to add `pyclass`-annotated structs for typed
channels, with the corresponding interface stub.

We can't export generic classes to Python, so we provide one for each
well-known Foxglove schema. Following the Rust SDK's logic when
implementing the `Encode` trait, this omits implementations for any
"Primitive" schemas.

It also exports a `PartialMetadata` type for the logging interface.

A follow-up PR will need to re-work the python module hierarchy a bit,
so that these modules can be used directly from `foxglove`, but the
changes here are enough to get the following to work:

```py
from foxglove._foxglove_py.schemas import SceneUpdate
from foxglove._foxglove_py.channels import SceneUpdateChannel
ch = SceneUpdateChannel("/test")
# ch.log(1) # TypeError
ch.log(SceneUpdate(entities=[], deletions=[]))
```

data.author: Bryan Fox
data.message:
Generate pyo3 schemas for SDK (#201)

This PR produces well-known Foxglove schemas as `pyclass`es which can be
used by [pyo3](https://pyo3.rs/) in the SDK. For the default channel
logging interface, we plan to remove protobuf serialization on the
python side, and instead use the existing serialization in SDK core.
We've demonstrated that this can be done with little relative overhead;
see FG-10358.

Most of the changes here are in `generatePyclass.ts`; per FG-10347,
we're going to simplify build steps between schemas and SDK. For now,
this produces output in a `pyclass` directory, and the build script for
the python SDK copies those files into the project. (Open to suggestions
here.)

The generator produces two files:

- the schemas, expressed as `pyclass`-annotated Rust structs & enums,
- the .pyi stub interface for the above,

Currently, the submodule is registered with a function call instead of a
declarative module. This mechanism is set to be deprecated in pyo3, but
integrating with hand-written python isn't straightforward. Once we have
the build process unified from FG-10347, it'll be a little easier to
make the declarative submodule syntax work.

data.message:
Add publish_status and remove_status methods to WebSocketServer (#192)

Relatively simple PR to add support for publishing status messages to
all connected clients, and removing them by list of ids.

[WS
Spec](https://github.com/foxglove/ws-protocol/blob/main/docs/spec.md#remove-status)

[Current Python
implementation](https://github.com/foxglove/ws-protocol/blob/main/python/src/foxglove_websocket/server/__init__.py#L457)

data.author: Adrian Macneil
data.message:
Remove legacy/invalid ROS messages (#203)

### Changelog
Removed some invalid / non-functional ROS messages from `foxglove_msgs`

### Docs
None

### Description
It appears that in https://github.com/foxglove/foxglove-sdk/pull/17 we
unintentionally committed some duplicate generated schemas with
incorrect names (the schemas were renamed during feedback on that PR).
These are not usable in Foxglove, and having them in the ros packages
might add confusion for users.

I discovered these by cleaning the ros output directories before
regenerating schemas.

This should not be a breaking change since the deleted schemas have
never been supported by Foxglove UI, but it is possible some people
might be unintentionally using them. For each deleted schema, there is
an officially supported alternative documented at
https://docs.foxglove.dev/docs/visualization/message-schemas/introduction,
for example `ArrowMarker` -> `ArrowPrimitive`, `ConeListMarker` ->
`SceneEntity`, etc.

data.author: Roman Shtylman
data.message:
Turn rust examples into packages (#199)

This change re-works the rust examples. Instead of all the examples
being sources as part of the "foxglove" package each example is now its
own package within the `rust/examples` folder. This makes it more
obvious which dependencies are needed for an example and isolates the
examples from each other. A reader can "copy-paste" an example as a
complete starting point (including the Cargo.toml file).

This change also does away with the "examples/common" folder. I found
this layer of indirection confusing for understanding the code I would
need to write.

Co-authored-by: Greg Smith <gasmith@foxglove.dev>

data.author: Eloff
data.message:
Core implement ws server listener interface for subs and adverts (#189)

Add new callbacks to ServerListener:

```
fn on_subscribe(&self, _channel_id: ChannelId) {}
fn on_unsubscribe(&self, _channel_id: ChannelId) {}
fn on_client_advertise(&self, _channel: &ClientChannel) {}
fn on_client_unadvertise(&self, _channel_id: ClientChannelId) {}
```

This mirrors how the callbacks are defined in the [Python
implementation](https://github.com/foxglove/ws-protocol/blob/main/python/src/foxglove_websocket/server/__init__.py#L508),
and they function in a similar way (e.g. not firing for duplicate or
erroneous requests)

I added RecordingServerListener to testutil to allow more easily testing
ServerListener.

I modified existing tests to verify these callbacks are called at the
appropriate times with the expected arguments, and not called for
duplicate requests.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Rework websocket blocking interface (#191)

I realized that we really need to expose a first-class blocking
interface for the websocket server, and not just for python. We really
don't want async-clueless programmers slapping a `#[tokio::main]` on
their entrypoint and then blocking tokio threads by accident. That'll be
a nightmare to detect and debug.

In this change:
- Add `WebSocketServer::tokio_runtime` to bring your own runtime
(unstable).
- Add `ws-demo-blocking.rs` example to demo a program without
`#[tokio::main]`.
- Split `WebSocketServerHandle` into a blocking and non-blocking
version.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
python: Revive ws-demo (#190)

Revive the python ws-demo, by creating a tokio runtime on demand.

Changes here:
- Create a runtime on demand if one doesn't exist.
- Hoist `get_runtime_handle()` out of `websocket.rs` to `runtime.rs` for
possible future reuse.
- Teach `get_runtime_handle()` to reuse the current runtime, if one
exists, instead of always creating a new one.
- Add a `shutdown_runtime` function, and invoke it from a python
`atexit` hook.
- Teach python to drop the GIL before calling into async code.

Those last two are critical for avoiding SIGABRTs and deadlocks during
python program exit. Since we use the `pyo3-log` forwarder, our tokio
threads have a tendency to grab the GIL for logging, which means that we
need to drop the GIL before blocking on anything going on in tokio.

Fixes: FG-10384
Fixes: FG-9902

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Replace HashSet<TopicByChannel> with a HashMap (#173)

While the `HashSet` might be slightly more memory-/cache-efficient, it's
causing some clippy indigestion. This is not a high-cardinality set, and
we're not accessing it on the hot path. We might as well just keep it
simple with a HashMap.

data.author: Greg Smith
data.message:
rust: Move tests indoors (#174)

We've had some confusion around which examples to follow. To avoid that,
let's bring our various internal tests and unstable examples inside the
crate, so we aren't forced to publicly expose things that we don't
intend to support.

Changes here:
- Moved test utilities to `crate::testutil`.
- Moved external tests to `crate::tests`.
- Reworked external examples to use public interfaces.
- Added docs to `FoxgloveError`, because this started out as an attempt
to do `#![warn(missing_docs)]`.
- Fixed tests that were incorrectly relying on `std::thread::sleep()`
inside a tokio runtime.
- Exposed `WebSocketServerHandle::publish_parameter_values()` under the
`unstable` feature to avoid unused_code/unused_import lints.
- Removed pub visibility for `crate::websocket`.

data.author: Jacob Bandes-Storch
data.message:
Fix PyPI publishing (#158)

Running a publish to TestPyPI immediately followed by a publish to the
"real" PyPI triggered [an
error](https://github.com/foxglove/schemas/actions/runs/12283736365/job/34277883747)
due to a file already existing. The workaround recommended in
https://github.com/pypa/gh-action-pypi-publish/issues/283#issuecomment-2499296440
is to set `attestations: false` on the TestPyPI publish.

data.author: jameskuszmaul-brt
data.message:
Add explicit field IDs to flatbuffer schemas (#148)

### Changelog
Added explicit field IDs to flatbuffer schemas.

### Docs

None

### Description

This allows the schemas to be compiled with `--require-explicit-ids`
turned on in `flatc`, which can be nice to help prevent people from
accidentally making breaking changes to flatbuffer schemas if they
choose to reorder fields (or insert new fields in the middle of the
schemas). Because of how flatc works with includes, if downstream users
want to use `--require-explicit-ids` on their own schemas that happen to
include foxglove schema types, they must update the foxglove schemas
that they use to include IDs.

data.author: Hans-Joachim Krauch
data.message:
Do not normalize time/duration types in generateRosMsgDefinition (#115)

### Public-Facing Changes

Do not normalize `time` & `duration` types in `generateRosMsgDefinition`

### Description
Changes `generateRosMsgDefinition` to not normalize `time` & `duration`
fields to their ROS2 equivalents (e.g. `builtin_interfaces/Time`). This
is now done in `generateRosMsg` as `generateRosMsgDefinition` should
output a message definition which is compliant with
[@foxglove/message-definition](https://github.com/foxglove/message-definition)
where e.g. `builtin_interfaces/Time` does not exist.

See
https://github.com/foxglove/rosmsg2-serialization/pull/17#issuecomment-1608102161

data.author: Jacob Bandes-Storch
data.message:
Export TS types from main; move generation exports under `internal` (#63)

**Public-Facing Changes**
Moved TypeScript types and enums to the main `@foxglove/schemas` entry
point; moved raw schema structures and generation functions to
`@foxglove/schemas/internal` entry point. Added
`@foxglove/schemas/jsonschema` entry point for JSON Schema.

Removed ESM outputs because without full package.json `"exports"`
support, importing from `@foxglove/schemas/internal` can only point to
one place, not intelligently one of `dist/cjs` or `dist/esm`. This
required removing the tsconfig `outDir`, so output files are placed
alongside source files.

The import syntax is now:
```ts
import { CompressedImage } from "@foxglove/schemas";  // TS type or enum
import { CompressedImage } from "@foxglove/schemas/jsonschema"; // json schema as POJO
import { foxgloveMessageSchemas } from "@foxglove/schemas/internal"; // internal representation of all schemas
```

**Description**
Resolves https://github.com/foxglove/schemas/issues/41

data.message:
Fix ROS packaging again (#40)

Rework CMake setup again to avoid using `..` by copying generated files into the ros_foxglove_msgs dir. This is necessary because bloom-release will end up copying the ros_foxglove_msgs dir only, losing access to files from the parent dir during the final build.

data.message:
Fix foxglove_msgs CMake (#35)

Fixed the install share directory for foxglove_msgs so that .msg files are stored under `share/foxglove_msgs/msg`. This avoids breaking other tools like rosbridge_server and rosbag2_storage_mcap. As a bonus, we no longer use symlinks which should improve Windows compatibility.

data.message:
Add Foxglove schemas and generate ros/proto/jsonschema definitions (#14)

**Public-Facing Changes**
This package is now published on NPM as `@foxglove/message-schemas`, and is the source of truth for message schemas supported by Foxglove Studio, which are documented in https://foxglove.dev/docs/studio/messages/introduction. We also generate ROS 1/2, Protobuf, JSON Schema, and TypeScript definitions from these schemas.

**Description**

The website will be updated to pull schemas from this repository.

- [ ] ~generate FileDescriptorSet for easy use with mcap/websocket~
- [x] generate TypeScript definitions for Node Playground
- [x] export TypeScript definitions from index.d.ts?
- [x] generate .msg for ROS 2
- [x] array lengths for matrices?
- [x] add other types

Closes https://github.com/foxglove/studio/issues/3043
